I'm wondering like how do other people do this? Like is there is there any sort of shortcut or are you basically just kind of [ __ ] the first time you hire a dev if you're like not that technical? Has anybody actually found a good workound for this? I've talked to >> there's this guy lots. He was one of the um first members of Consumer Club and he was on this channel as well. I interviewed him and he uses Upwork for all his apps. He he's like a multi- uh time founder. He built all these iOS apps and he just he hires out of uh Upwork every time. And I think there's just some basic stuff that you can do. Like he says that you basically just you got to break down the functions of the app into at least three parts, like three to five parts, and then put a price on each of the parts. Because one of the biggest problems is the costs bloat over time when the dev says like, "Oh, sorry. This is taking longer than I expected." And then you just don't know how to say no to that. You're just like, "Okay, I guess I'll trust you." But part of it is is also like chachbt where you you know you can use chatbt to estimate you know how complex are each of these features and then put a price on that based on a benchmark of you know what are the costs and then he just has his own like I don't know if this is arbitrary but he just sets his own like cap on each iOS app. So, he's he has like very problem-solving type of apps that are just painpoint solution, hard payw wall, and all he does is um I think his cap is like something around $2,000. So, he never pays more than like $2,000 per iOS app. I think that requires just good SOPs, good vetting, and negotiating on price. I think a lot of people just don't negotiate on price or are really clear about like build this part it's $500 this part 1,000 this part like 200 and the core feature should always be like actually the least for him at least he says it's the least labor intensive part the core uh feature of the app and the onboarding and stuff like that is like the most labor intensive >> when you're doing hard payw wall stuff especially like your sales pipeline is like the the onboarding experience and the payw All I want to talk about the lif style too a little bit. Some people are curious. They go to the bio and they click the link. Yeah, that's how we were driving that funnel there. So, that one had the hook and bow out. You actually show the the affirmation on the screen of the app and you're showing the app as it's going. So, that one I imagine is more high converting. So, this one format is really interesting. It's very engaging, but then it's also showing the app and mentioning the name of the app. And it's also kind of repeatable because you're saying, "Hey, if you're watching this before February 7th, insert whatever date it is like right now." So, it feels timely. It feels relevant. So, is that basically the strategy? You kind of repeat the same format, but then you just change the date and it it's sort of like a evergreen format that you can just keep repeating. This was like our initial format. Since then, we've expanded to like multiple formats and like multiple features. And to your point, it is like super repeatable. The creator that we were inspired by is a girl named Sarah Pearl. She sells courses. She sells books. She's in like the manifesting niche. And she doesn't do this type of content anymore, but she did this for like 2 and 1/2 years. Got a million followers on Instagram, 2 and a half million followers on Tik Tok. So, it's like the same cadence of like having something repeatable that is a motivational gets people out of their seat. and bucket this in like the hope course side of social media. She did this because she saw like another self-help book. It got a million purchases on Tik Tok shop and then she made a book for herself and she would repeat that content and she sold like a 100,000 copies of her book literally just saying like repeat these affirmations for the next 7 days. So we were like we could probably do that as an app. It's exactly like you said it's an info product, right? It's a book. You can turn that into an app. like a person buys a book one time or can buy an app that's like a recurring subscription that basically provides the same type of value. How did you find this person? Cuz this is a gold mine. Like I think if you apply the framework and you're trying to find another niche where you can turn person who sells courses into an app, but then people might not be aware of all the niches of where people sell courses and the types of content that they're doing really well. Do you remember how you found this Sarah person? >> Once we got that 10 million view video, me and Chloe were scrolling to try and find all right, who are the larger creators in the space in the self-help, wellness, mindset, motivation, and just by naturally scrolling and warming up new accounts. We ran into Sarah. I would probably aim for that like 500,000 plus follower, probably like a million to look and see like what products are they selling, do they have a link in bio, how are they trying to monetize? If you're the app founder, you're the brand and you want to sponsor creators to achieve similar distribution, but then you own the app, they don't own the app. Where in that curve do you go? Are you going to that kind of middle ground medium-siz influencer who will take the brand deals or are you actually going big and just partnering with those people or do you go small to the micro influencers? You have to start smaller because you have like an unproven product and once you do target like people with like a million followers, they do have like a brand that they have to maintain. So if product isn't there yet and it usually isn't in your first like 2 3 months you have to figure out really like what your core product mechanics are what's like the hooked model what gets people in what's the action they take you know what are they rewarded with and ideally if you can build like a product that lasts you have some sort of investment I would start out going to the people in the like 50k like 250k range in terms of Tik Tok following I mean that's what we did we were paying a bunch of those like smaller size creators because they're not getting brand deals. You're still actually working like a part-time job or like a full-time job for the most part. There's this opportunity for you as an app founder to sell your brand and to have like a mutually beneficial partnership. Ideally, you should be aiming for like a $1 like CPM. You can up that as you go along. I think that's really where the art of advertising comes in. And when you're starting out, going with those smaller creators will just get you people in the funnel to understand those metrics so you can optimize and scale. >> So you you scaled to 40 creators. I want to talk about that in a bit. But you said in order to scale to that amount and really be able to start investing, you got to fix your funnel first, like make sure your LTV is high enough to support that growth. How did you actually get a good like high converting retentive product in order to support that growth? So, I remember when we first started out, our install to payw wall rate was like 50 55%. We had about like a 15 to 20% conversion from like payw wall to trial, which is like a decent standard, but like I said, only 50% of people were getting there because we didn't build up enough consumer trust in our onboarding for them to just immediately log in and like type their goals. So you're getting 50% view rate on the pay wall itself. So half of the people were dropping off just scrolling through the four screens. I have our Figma files up here. Initially our onboarding was like this login screen. What's your name? And then type in your goals. And then after you typed in your goals, you got like that day in your dream life. But like I said, everyone dropped off here because we didn't build enough trust in our onboarding for people to actually share their dreams and goals despite the fact that they had that user intent from our UGC content. So that's why we expanded our onboarding a little more, added in some social proof, onboarding video, a couple questions along the way, and then that got us from 50 to 60% to 85 to 90%. Just a couple questions to better understand your customer and make that experience feel personal doubled our conversion. That is a huge difference. What were the biggest things in your onboarding that you feel like make the biggest difference in that conversion? I would really say, and this is where like the ecom pros have really gotten it right, the social proof I think is really important. Being able to say like, you know, proven methods, meaningful results, those small things, they're not like outrageous claims, but just saying that like this is our inspiration. These are people who have done these things before have really helped. And like I said, just really asking like progressive questions. People don't want to go in an app and like immediately type in a paragraph. having buttons that you can click despite like chat GPT and like chat being like a great interface and people will still expect some type of dopamine physical trigger in an app. That's why Dolingo is so successful. These screens are super simple. It feels like a PowerPoint almost like there's just very minimal words on each screen and you tap through and it makes it a lot more consumable. It's almost like Tik Tok captions. You don't put more than like five words on each screen. You like switch to the next frame. It's definitely like the model here. As much as you want to like provide like information for a user, like everyone has Tik Tok brain nowadays, they're not going to read like a paragraph anymore. >> I think you have a hot takes around payw walls. >> Yeah, I do. If you do a hard payw wall, it's honestly because your app is but if you look at like apps that are actually like useful and helpful, Strava gives you a free trial and you get entrenched and then you're like, hm, you know what? I probably should pay for like Strava Premium. Like eventually you have this emotional trigger where it's like, "Oh yeah, I'm trying to learn a lesson. I get the dopamine hit and if I like want to continue getting more of these dopamine hits, I should pay for it." But because a lot of these leaks aren't closed on like the current state of like mobile apps, it's really just like how can we create the most like viral feature and then like that's it. You lose the ability to actually build like an app that people stay on. And without that, you can't do like a premium model cuz you will have conversions. >> So it's like if you have a hard payw wall and a good product that has the investment and the variable reward and all this stuff, is that also good? Does that like fit into your view? An app like Cal AI, it's like all right, like I want to lose weight. I want to get stronger. There's like a good emotional hook here. It's like you have an external trigger like what gets the user to the product like the external dopamine and it's like okay great. Like I'm trying to lose weight. What's like the simplest action I can take? I can take a picture of my food and then the variable reward is calories. Calorie tracking is something that you can do like every day if you're trying to lose weight, get stronger, build more muscle, a little healthier because over time you can see these patterns of like, oh, here's like my food, here are my calories track. It's like a slot machine essentially. Like you don't really know what you're going to get, but there's no investment there. There's no actual product there. And you could have like a really good top of the funnel and keep shoving people in there as long as your rorowaz and your payback period makes sense, but like you'll never get that model that like actually made flow into like a billion dollar company cuz there's no investment there. >> How do you think about asking for more investment from the user? If you want to actually figure out how to get people to stay and like go like a great app, try to figure out what that bottom of the funnel is. So it's like what does that user experience look like? You know if you get to day 30, day 7, day 1, like what is the expectation and work backwards from that. The easiest path to 100K trigger action variable reward. And then if you want to go bigger than that and build a retentive app that people keep coming back to, probably something that has some enterprise value or exit value. That's where you need to figure out the investment part. And for the investment part, you want to figure out what's a user action that people are already doing. In your case, what is recently ubiquitous, newly possible? >> What's recently ubiquitous for like the consumer is being able to have all this access to your own data in the palm of your fingertips. And what's newly possible is that we have these like LLMs before a lot of these like insights would have to be hardcoded, but you really see this in Strava right now. I think really building the Strava for stress and mental health is like a good proxy for what we want to do. So like these little insights that I would have never been able to actually like gather from purely looking at my data around like my runs is now recently possible. So that's how we're thinking about how to do this. The goal is to build something helpful, useful, and stands the test of time. I think that's sort of like the fundamental problem with self-help. It's that it requires yourself to put in a bunch of effort to improve yourself. But if you find an action that people naturally do every day like have a heart rate or take a walk or do things that are stressful, it doesn't require any user input and then give them insights into how they can improve their life which is newly possible with LLM cuz you're getting all this data and now you put it into the LLM and then you feed back like helpful stuff and solutions to the user. How did you scale from this one winning format that's getting millions of views and then scale that to 40 creators? you just see still I think one of the best ways we saw through like our metrics that most people coming in our funnel were like girls like 18 to like 25. So we used platforms like Sideshift a great UGC marketplace to be able to like hire creators like really quickly that got us about 10 20 people that were actually really good. Like I said is just a matter of like how do you use all the tools out there? You know there are agencies available as well. We did have that winning format, but one thing that I also saw was like really viral during that time were like people crashing out cuz Chloe was like making content and then like one day she just like made a video like ranting. Our friend was like you should tell Chloe to like stop crashing out and it got the wheels turning and I was like crashing out is actually like really viral thing in itself. People being mad, it's like a very strong emotion. People resonate with it. They think it's funny and always goes viral. But I think at that same time like Justin Bieber was like promoting his album and like everyone was talking about his crashs. There was that video of him in front of Nou Malibu where he was like, "Dude, is it not like clocking to you, bro? Like I'm like a dad, too. Like I have a family." And then he used that as like a billboard in like West Hollywood. Literally, it was like his album logo and it was like, "Is it not clocking to you?" And like a picture of like Justin Bieber. It was like such like a viral concept already. We also invented this crash out button or like a really big red button and you click like crash out now and then it gave you like a breathing exercise to do. We had one video that got like 12 million views because of that. It was like a slideshow. >> That's a great video. You literally showed the app in it. It's just a funny text about crashing out. >> If it was like a 15 million view video and it was like a hook and demo like it probably would have gotten I would say like 30 40,000 downloads. How many views did this video get? 13 million views, 10 to 15k downloads from one just two slides on Tik Tok when you're talking to all these 40 creators, are you doing the same creative strategy for all of them at the same time? Are you kind of giving them free reign to just be creative? So, when it comes to like actual UGC creators and like college ambassadors, we try to be more strict with the guidelines. They're not like professional creators. They don't know like the angles, the hooks and demos. But for a lot of people, it's like I said, those small things will matter a lot more. But when you're at 40 creators, and when we were at 40 creators, like there's also room to AB test, it was still inherently like the same guidelines of like do a slideshow, do this hook and demo, and show like the same product. The first 10 seconds where we were trying to AB test to find like the most viral, varying degrees of success with like different hooks. The demo and the product just stays the same. But I've also been looking at all these like ecom guys. This guy named Dc Midas like tweets like insane like alpha. These are the things that go viral if you're trying to target somebody over like 45. Go to your mom's Facebook page and she'll see like this and then people like try to like run ads that are like UGC. But you have to understand like you have to meet your market where they are whether that's the channel, the content they see. And that's what really separates like a longerlasting marketer. Literally people like run advertising agencies outside of consumer apps and products and they they're able to see things like this and they're like, you know what, yeah, I can't target like a 25-year-old with this, but like this is great rorowaz. That's some alpha. It's good to go into like hyper competitive spaces to figure out where the tactics are, like where the real edge is. Cuz in ecom, especially affiliate ecom where you're selling something that's like very much a commodity and your only edge is your rorowaz, your marketing. you can take a lot of those principles and take them to consumer apps. I don't see a ton of people doing that because a lot of people in apps I feel like have more Silicon Valley backgrounds or you know coding backgrounds. They're not really in the trenches of e-commerce and affiliate but that's a good like mindset shift if you're a consumer app founder thinking about trying to absorb more information from spaces that are hyper competitive in the marketing space. >> You have to run ads eventually. It's like really hard not to. And the reality is like if you're all bidding for the same CPM with like the same format, it's just going to skyrocket. So like your ability to innovate and target new channels and audiences and demographics is what makes like a really good marketer. For example, at Sony and like Dolingo, they have different accounts for different countries and different activities. And that's how you really expand your funnel horizontally. But I wouldn't immediately do this unless you actually know what you're doing. And even then, like you should really try and focus on dominating like one funnel, one niche. Try to get that two, 3x rorowaz first. This like applies to apps just as much as it does like an ecom product and you need to like dominate one channel otherwise like your focus and your attention is just going to be off the charts and you'll never actually wet any channel. Is there anything else that you wanted to share? I feel like there's a lot of good stuff in this. >> If you're building consumer app, this is really like the model that you should think about. You start off with capital, code, time, money. This is like top of the funnel. So it's like all right you have creators posts that they make views impressions. More creators means more post which means more views which means more impressions. Try to get a really good CPM so you can justify like a good cost basis there. And then you also have like ASOS app store conversion. You can get 100 million views but if your name is like something super popular like you're not going to be found in the app store. If your name is like AI journal, like you're going to be screwed. So that's why it's good to have like some type of brand name, something that's like culturally relevant. From there, you get your downloads, then you can use a service like super wall to like really help you AB test your payw wall. ## [10/28] Meet The Guy Who Solved Growing Apps (Hunter Isaacson Interview)
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTree0unT_0
Duration: 29:49
Words: 6,566

Prior to NGI, I had like over 70 million downloads on other apps that I had built over the course of the beginning of my career. And I think that opportunity is still very much open. At some point, there will be a very successful crypto game. I think Vault kind of wanting it to happen. People want it. It's just no one's packaged it right. If you were currently at 10K MR with an app, you want to really scale and you have, let's say, like a $10,000 budget, what would you do? good amount of that money should be put towards. Today we're doing a deep dive with one of the most prolific app builders of all time. He's built apps like NGL and Bags. Over the years, these have done insane numbers. Hundreds of millions of downloads, 8 figures revenue, all while staying extremely profitable. This is none other than Hunter Isacson. I've seen some people criticize mass virality for consumer apps. The beauty of NGL is it's like a really tight viral loop. We found that a lot of people that churned out of the product ended up coming back in. He's done a few other podcasts and I've watched some of them, but what makes this one special is we got super tactical and as actionable as possible. I asked him to go into the nitty-gritty details of exactly what strategies he's using to go viral and make money with his apps. He showed me all his actual Figma files of all his app screens. And towards the end, I asked him pretty deep questions about how he would use the same strategies today with the current trends. Let's get right into it. How's NGL doing? >> It's doing great. 3 years later, still doing great. We have 150 million monthly active users on the product, which is way more than I ever expected to be honest with you. Yeah, it's done very, very well. >> That's awesome. What do you think it takes to be good at viral consumer apps? Could you think of one thing? >> I think like knowing how human beings act when they're put in like a group scenario, right? Understanding group think, understanding why people do what they do. I think that's why I've been successful in social because I'm really good at understanding like when a person looks at a screen, when they look at anything, what are they going to feel and then how do those emotions dictate the the action that we're requesting them to do. >> That's awesome. Can you just walk through the journey of NGL a little bit for people who don't know yet? >> Yeah, for sure. We started the company right when Instagram released the link feature for everybody. It used to be that you could only post links if you had 10,000 followers. So, you know, only people that were influencers basically could ever chill anything on their story. So, they changed this at the end of October of 2021. And that's literally right when we started building the app. Like the second that we saw this, myself and a few friends of mine, we got a Zoom call on Halloween and we were like, we need to build a product for this. What's the most viral thing we can think of? And we're like, let's build an anonymous messaging platform on top of Instagram. The consumer world is so small. We thought everyone was going to do this. We thought this was going to be like the number one thing people were going to build. So our focus was like how do we build this in like as fast as possible. We built the app in about a month, but then it was like 6 months of nobody using it. So it's like our assumption that everybody saw the opportunity was like so wrong. No one cloned us until after we went viral. That 6 months was very hard. We tried a lot of different things. You know, we rebranded the app first just designed wise. Then I changed the name. I came up with the name NGL. We got a sick domain ngl.link and we basically spent money purely on how to activate the graph. So we were like testing here and there influencers, you know, like $100 here, $100 there, paying someone to post the Instagram story, you know, Tik Toks, just trying things. About 4 months into the sixmonth period, we had that first like tiny little blip, like very small, and it was from an influencer who we paid to post the link. She activated a school on the other side of the world. Then it spread and infected, you know, the other schools in the area, but it didn't expand to another country. It kind of just stayed in this graph. So, we realized that the problem was this was like more of a lower income country. So, we were like, well, we got to build Android. So, we built Android very quickly. This is now May of 2022. The second we finished Android, we then did another round of marketing and it was one Tik Tok that went viral and then that was it. It activated everybody and took over the world over the next week. What was that Tik Tok? It's a Tik Tok of a girl and she's like showing one of her NGL messages. Someone said, "Oh, I was with your boyfriend last night or your boyfriend said this about you." And it was like the girl like, you know, get a hint on who sent me the message. Right. So, it was kind of like one of those really funny like gotcha type Tik Toks and it blew up. It got like a million views very quickly. >> That's crazy. What was the hook of that video? It sounds kind of similar to stuff that goes viral today. It was really like a controversial crazy message to get from someone, you know. So, it was like we tried this with a bunch of different message texts, you know, just like funny, controversial stuff, edgy that just would catch your eye when you were like scrolling TikTok. And then we always kind of related it back into the platform of like, oh, you can get so many messages from people and yeah, you might be able to like potentially find out who sent the message super excited like, oh, I'm going to download that. And that's what activated like our first thousand users in one day was from that Tik Tok. I've seen some people criticize like mass virality on Tik Tok like for consumer apps and they say like even if you get a bunch of users they'll turn out. So, but it seems like that wasn't the case for you guys. How did you like handle the virality and actually take advantage of it? >> The beauty of NGL is it's like a really tight viral loop. We found that a lot of people that turned out of the product ended up coming back in because their friends would still post NGL links. You know, in some countries it's like every teenager, you know, all the 17, 18, 19 year olds, right? all those people that are in like that that high school college era, it's their link in bio. If you turn out, you're going to ultimately come back in because you're going to see your friend post their link. Maybe it'll be in their bio. You'll send them a message and they'll realize, "Oh, wait. I kind of want to do this now, too." So, it had churn for sure, but it also had this like very high reddownload rate, which I think is what's allowed it to continue to be so popular today. >> That's interesting. Yeah. So, it really became a habit and part of people's core day-to-day, but then also you got that real estate which is the link in bio. This is consumer social like people are interacting with each other, but you guys are also monetized. So, can you talk about the the revenue side of things? >> Yeah, for sure. I mean, the revenue is done very well. It's a multi-8 figure a year business. I think the the revenue is primarily it's just derived through weekly subscription in different countries. It's priced differently depending on the region and depending on the GDP per capita of that country. So, it's always like a low impulse buy. You know, anywhere between a dollar and $7. So, it's pretty cheap. And I'd say a very small percentage of our downloads actually monetized. It's primarily used as a free product. It's really only for like power users that want, you know, to see more insights about who's sending them their messages or viewing their profile or they want to, you know, post different, you know, we call them different link games that we have. But it's primarily a free product. It's just because of the volume of users, we've been able to generate significant revenue just by taking a very small percentage of those users and moving them to paid. I feel like there's two types of consumer startups. There's like pure consumer social like Facebook, Instagram, and they monetize with ads cuz they have billions of users. And then there's single player utility apps, a lot of the AI apps that you see these days like GPT rappers. But then you guys are kind of in the middle where you're you're consumer social but you're also monetized. I'm curious like so you started in 2021 so you've had four years to build this company. Do you think that this genre of do a mass consumer kind of social product monetized? Absolutely. I think the opportunity is still there. I think everything that I've done in social that's been successful have been things that are built on top of existing networks. So I did this previously before NGL. Prior to NGL, I had like over 70 million downloads on other apps that I had built over the course of the beginning of my career. And I think that opportunity is still very much open. I think it comes down to where you're targeting for the graph, right? We target Instagram, you could target Snapchat, you could target X, you could target, you know, Facebook and, you know, go for the the 45-year-old moms, right? It doesn't really matter. I do think that you can still build consumer products and you can monetize them in a simple way and grow them on the backs of these like behemoth networks. That's interesting. Do you think you're essentially competing with the big platforms? You're getting attention from them on the platform and then you're pulling them off the platform and I guess augmenting their experience with Instagram or whatever it is, but do you feel that you're sort of at odds with them? It doesn't compete with the big networks. I think it does enhance or augment the experience of using it. That's a great way to put it. Like you can use Instagram the exact same way, but you just tap this link. It opens inside of Instagram. your experience is only slightly interrupted from scrolling and then you can very quickly either go and do it yourself, right, by downloading the app or you just close it and go to the next story, right, and just kind of on. So, it's like a lightweight interruption to the flow, but it's very easy to like bypass it or just go through the flow. It's not going to be like a 10-minute funnel. Sorry, very quick interruption. Hunter is a member of Consumer Club. It's an online community for app founders to meet each other. You should apply to join consumer club and meet Hunter inside. This pod is also sponsored by Superwwell. Thanks so much Superwwell for helping put this together. The home screen, it's a two-step copy link, then share. When you tap share, you're given this screen. These are animated gifts. And then it tells you, you know, click the sticker button, click the link button, you know, add the link to your story, and then frame the link. Right? That was the whole concept. If you just post it with our flow like this, we will automatically copy this asset. We'll pull your profile picture and we'll put it in here and make it look really nice and then you tap it. It opens up a window. You can tap the dice. You'll get ideas if you don't know what to tell people what to say. There's a persistent download button at the bottom. And then once you send it, we then tell you to get your own messages or you can just go back and send another one. It's pretty straightforward. And then it looks like this when you get them on the app and you can tap it here and then you can either get a hint which we can reveal like type of phone the user has or the rough location or you can reply and reply basically just copies it onto your story and then you can respond to it. >> What I really love about this is like just the copywriting of get your own messages. When you think about it, the result of that call to action, you sell the end result, right? Which is what they'll get if they actually do follow the steps. And then once they're hooked, they get into the flow and then they download the app and they follow the instructions. You're almost like leading with, oh, this is super easy. You're just going to get your own messages. And then you kind of have to educate them as you go. >> 100%. And it's way easier to get a download by saying get your own messages than saying, hey, download this app. And that's why we we have like a very very it's still a very very high ratio of like new users hitting this screen and immediately going to the app store and downloading it. And the beauty of this app is, you know, our onboarding 15, 20 seconds, right? It's like very quickly we bring you and and drop you onto this screen right here. A big lesson I learned with apps is just how do you make it like one flow, one funnel, and don't over complicate it and just focus on like a northstar metric. In the case of NGL, our northstar metric was like how many people are posting the link and then they're posting like at least two replies. >> That's so interesting. So I feel like nailing that first kind of core set of users is really important. Another question I had is this is not a completely new invention like there's anonymous messaging app came before this but did not take advantage of this exact platform shift that you talked about which is the link in Instagram story. I'm curious if is this the way that you think of products in general like tying an existing concept with a new platform arbitrage? Is that like a way to always think about startups or are there other frameworks that you think about starting products? That's definitely a good framework I would say like find existing things that happen on other networks or other distribution mechanisms and just switch the distribution mechanism and improve the product to a certain degree and and you're right you know before NGL there's YOLO yik asm we could go all the way back I mean formspring like this is a behavior on the internet that's existed for a long time I do think that the reason NGL went as big as it did and has more downloads than all of those apps is because we use the biggest distribution graph of all which is the Instagram graph. That's why it did so well. But NGL also is huge on other platforms, too. Twitter, it's big on WhatsApp. Like, it's big across the board, I think, also because a lot of these anonymous apps have over complicated them after they were successful, right? They added feeds and they added complicated profile tools and like if you look at NGL today and you look at NGL when it went viral, it's very, very similar. It's not changed to a large order of magnitude. I'd say that it's more been optimized and refined and that we found ways to just like make the product cooler and more fun and more engaging, but we didn't, you know, add multiple more tabs and, you know, make it super confusing. Like, it stayed relatively the same. >> I like how you said distribution graph. So when when people think of distribution graphs and you know if someone wants to build a startup that uses the same framework and they're thinking about the major distribution graphs there's like you said Twitter X, Instagram, Facebook, Snapchat, maybe YouTube. Do you think that there's an underutilized or almost like an an arbitrage opportunity looking at smaller graphs that are still powerful? Is there anything like that that you're noticing these days? I >> I mean there's definitely an opportunity there for sure. I think I'm kind of seeing an emergence of more of these smaller graph type apps, right? Like I'm seeing these. I do think there's an opportunity there for sure. But I also think that like you could build a super viral experience, put it on Twitter and it will work, right? Like you don't have to go and only find the smaller graphs and the newer apps or like the very like niche communities. You could still use a big platform and just, you know, have a a good viral loop and it will work. This is the OG right here. This is what started it all. This app actually never made it to the app store, which is funny. It died in test flight. It took two and a half years to build this app. The general concept of this one, I was seeing all these influencers blow up on social media and I was seeing that a lot of them like didn't post interesting content. So, I wanted to figure out a way to like kind of create a different graph where the cooler things you do and the more times you hang out with your friends, like the more times people see your content to encourage like viral moments. Extremely hard problem to solve. And I solved it in an even more difficult problem. The UI is very confusing. Even though this app failed, I just loved the process of designing it so much that I realized that like this is what I should be doing with my life. But yeah, this was a spectacular failure. Good lessons learned though. I started this app though in 2017. So it took 2 and 1/2 years just to like go through multiple iterations, different designs, paid a development agency. And this one I fully sunset in 2020. And then I built this one next. This is Zoom University. We had the idea of like let's build a double dating app for college kids and it started with it was like we literally was like a meme because like Zoom University was a meme at the time and we were like let's just like embrace the meme. So we like went on meme pages and posted content and just like funny stuff. What it did is it like just got everybody excited about it and we had a weight list of like 40,000 people and it was a 7:1 girl to guy ratio which is in dating is unheard of. And that was a a real lesson I learned of like women will do things because they're really comfortable that they're with another woman. That's what made it so great is cuz like if you're a young girl, you don't want to go on like a video chat app and talk to some random guy. Like that's kind of uncomfortable. But if you had your best friend with you and you're going to get two guys that come in and we had like, as you can see, there was like a little group chat and then a private chat. You could open these up and then the girls will say, "Oh, these guys are weird. Let's leave." And then both people would have to match or both people would have to skip. It made it like this cool experience of like quadruple opt-in basically like double opt-in on both sides. And then if you matched, you'd be thrown into a group chat and you would just save everybody's profile pictures and you guys could just like give each other your Instagrams, Snapchats, whatever. This one did I want to say somewhere like maybe a couple hundred thousand downloads, but it went top 10 in the app store in the social category. >> I remember the Zoom University Facebook group. Did you guys own that? I'd have to ask my buddy Danny, but I know we were in every single Facebook group for every college. The V1 of this app was actually done over Zoom, which was funny. Like sending meeting codes and then we built this app very, very quickly. That's wild. I like the private chat and then the public chat. It definitely solves that problem. Like the next one I built did 70 million downloads. This is Wink. Premise behind it originally was that we wanted to make it really easy for people to exchange Snapchats with each other. all these young people are bored and they're at home and it's locked down and Snapchat doesn't have a good social graph for like friend suggestions. So, we kind of just had the idea, let's build like a really simple way to just like swipe on people like Tinder and instead of adding them on the app, it would just add them on Snapchat. This is another one that I built. This was I built in the same era as Wink. The idea here was we wanted to create a different way where people could make friends. I designed these games myself and you know we had it where like you would just tap on a game or you tap this button it would randomly match you. This was a cool animation showing like people that were in games and then you had a uh a microphone option here. So very simple app. This app had like some of the highest average time spent of any app I've ever built. Close to an hour per user. I feel like games PvP with real money is just such an insane concept. It combines the hourlong retention of gaming. What's your take on crypto with PVP games? Will happen. It's a question of when. A lot of the people have tried many years at this point, but I'd say that if you're going to build a crypto app is a whole other beast than anything else. At some point there will be a very successful crypto game. I think we've all kind of been wanting it to happen since especially since last cycle, the 2021 cycle and we had like the Axi Infinities of the World and all these other games. Like people want it, it's just no one's packaged it right. I think it comes down to just building a really good product. Sometimes when your focus is on the money aspect, you don't focus as much on the actual player and the app experience and the social graph. It's also very very hard to acquire customers in gaming. It's a very competitive space. Most of it is run by paid. So if you're a small guy and you're starting out, games is not where you start. It's double hard. It's like you have to make a fun game that retains users for an hour plus. That's so hard. and then acquiring the users. The limits will only get higher. >> I guess my main question is how does this make money? >> So, it makes money off of transaction volume whenever there's a big spike in onchain volume. We make a a 1% fee on transactions and then we pass back the majority of that fee to your friend who invited you to the app. Or if you're in a group chat, someone posts a token, you buy it from them, then they'll earn some of that commission as well. And then we also have a token launchpad product where you can create your own coin, launch it. Our spin on it though is we do a 1% royalty. Not just earning on the LP transaction, actually earning like on every single trade. You could run up $2 million of volume and you'll make $20,000 really easily, really fast. And we're also building like pretty crazy things I can't talk about right now, but it will make it even better. I wanted to ask you about a very specific idea, and I want to talk about a specific app and just get your take on it. This is a recipe sharing app. Basically, you scroll through Instagram. There's a share button that pops up. When you click share, the recipe icon, like the app icon is right there, and you can share it to the recipe app. The recipe app scans the video, like the Tik Tok or the Instagram, and then it generates a recipe with all the ingredients and the quantities from the video itself. Most app developers aren't really thinking about the share menu as a piece of real estate, but it is. One interesting thing is also that it's not actually that easy to get your app onto the share menu. Once it's there, it looks good, but to get it there, it takes, I think, three or four taps total. To scroll over, tap more and then edit, add, and then scroll and drag it up to the first position and then click done. And then now it's there forever. The recipe faves playbook is definitely a good playbook. If the users understand the value of the product, like they really get the value and why it's so important, then you could put a multi-step tutorial in front of them. That's what worked for NGL. Like they knew the value of NGL because they saw their friends get messages. So when they got to the app and then they tap share and it's four steps, they don't really care cuz they've kind of already been sold this concept of like what they're getting. Someone go build this and then get advised by Hunter. I have another idea I want to get your take on. Did you know that there are iOS Safari extensions? I love adding, you know, invite screens, forcing users to share. I think it's a great way to get stamp of approval from someone. If you text your friend an app or you post an app on your story, for example, it's like an endorsement. I'm a big fan of that. I put that in every product. There's always, you know, easy ways to invite people as long as it actually makes sense. If you were currently at 10K MR with an app, you want to really scale. So, you kind of have some product market fit and you have, let's say, like a $10,000 budget, what would you do? Like, what are the channels that you think are interesting right now? Curious if you have a take on that. So, you're a 10,000 MR and you want to scale. What do you do with the 10,000? Let's say you have 20K a month budget actually. Okay. 20K a month. Good amount of that money should be put towards either UGC with influencers or ads. But what I would do is I would break it up into like experiments, right? So you experiment what cohort came from which ad or which Tik Tok video and then constantly be adapting the formats and adapting it but doing smaller tests, right? Don't spend all the money on like, you know, one specific creative. I would just test like a dozen of them. I'd really focus on like productled growth. How do you use those ads in the in the UGC to just bring people in and then how do you get those people to immediately invite a friend, right? So like that's also something that's important like having a social functionality where you know that when you spend something whatever your CPI is it's actually considerably lower because a certain percentage of users are bringing somebody else. Those two things kind of come together like what's the best hook to get somebody in? Is it an ad? Is it a video on Tik Tok? And then once you have them in, can you get X% to just share it? And then I would say your focus should just be on scaling all of that content up and finding other distribution mechanisms and just spending your money primarily on like tests cuz then you'll basically you'll hit like a format that works. You'll hit like a specific ad that works and then you've also solved the productled growth problem of like getting people to invite. So it's just like that's the where the flywheel really kicks off. That's how I would do it. I just spend it on getting more users in. >> Super actionable. Love it. Thanks so much Hunter. This is amazing having you. super tactical. I learned a lot. ## [11/28] Meet The Guy Dominating The App Store
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcDOgWGh4bc
Duration: 54:09
Words: 11,103

How do you build a portfolio of 30 apps with over 50 million downloads? >> Yeah, probably more to be honest. I haven't really kept count. >> You build a factory. Ryan's team built a system so effective it turned one of their apps into the number one most downloaded app in the US beating Tik Tok and Google. >> We heard of like Tik Tok at that time, you know, Google, Chrome, all the other apps that everyone downloads every day. But seeing the number one downloaded app on that day was just insane. But the crazy part, even with the factory, they still couldn't explain [music] their biggest hit, a creator who repeatedly got tens of millions of views for reasons they still don't quite understand. Top left one, 66.9 million. It just went super viral. We tried to replicate the same video across 20, 30, 40 different content creators. Didn't work. She did another video back to back, hit again. I don't know why. It's just makes no sense to me. >> So, how do they build a predictable system around unpredictable results? First, they built an in-house university to train an army of 250 content [music] creators and turn them from amateurs into professionals who understand all the relevant metrics. >> We had a really large content creator army that we built inhouse, effectively created our own kind of university teaching them how to make good ads, good content [music] for us. >> Second, they created a three tier ad scaling system. Every video gets a $20 test. Winners graduate to a level two campaign with a bigger budget. And the top 1% of those become level three evergreens that get 90% of the [music] ad spend. >> You might get to a point where you just have the same video running at level one, level two, and level three, just at different scale spends. That was effectively the model. >> Third, they mastered seasonal ad buying arbitrage, spending 75% of their entire annual ad budget in January when the cost to acquire a user is 50% cheaper. The first week of January is effectively the Super Bowl, the Black Friday of results where you just have so many market tailwind wins with you. We would spend effectively like 75% of our ad budget within the first month of the year. >> Ryan's whole approach was not based around trying to find [music] a viral trend or just ride waves of hype. It was to build a machine that could test thousands of videos, identify winners, and scale [music] them systematically. we could allocate certain amount of content, maybe thousands of videos across [music] the portfolio in as profitable a way as we could based off of the metrics that was coming off the back of the the [music] ads that were being created. And in this episode, Ryan opens up the entire playbook. How to build a creator army from scratch, his [music] three tier system for scaling ads from $20 to millions of dollars and how he's now building an AI employees to run his entire playbook for him. We are creating AI employees for your mobile app and then in the background while you sleep, it's just going to grow your app. It's going to find problems. It's going to make sure that they're fixed. This is a masterass in building an industrial app growth factory. Let's get into it. This is the Superall podcast and I'm Joseph Choy, founder of Consumer Club. The members in the Consumer Club Discord and the founders I interview on the pod build apps at a median of about a million dollars ARR. In my conversations with dozens of these founders every week, one thing I've noticed is most of them AB test their payw walls to increase their conversion rates and make more money. Now, most people know that one of the best ways to AB test payw walls is Superwall. But one thing you might not know is Superwall has a lot of data on the thousands of apps that use their payw walls. So recently, they actually put together a tool that takes 422 profitable paywall experiments and put those into a paywall experiment generator where you can upload a screenshot of your own paywall and it'll give you an experiment idea to increase your revenue. You can use it for free at paywallexperiments.com. All right, let's get into the pod. So you have 30 apps in your portfolio and a few of them have 7 figure AR. It was Reflectly your first app in the portfolio? >> Yes. So, Reflectly was the original app that was built back in 2017 and then at the time it was the AI journaling app before AI was a thing. It was kind of just a combination of machine learning and then from 2017 to 2020 uh we scaled that relatively large. Um mainly we had just a really good arbitrage with Facebook ads. Um we were doing micro influencers at the time. So finding UGC before it was a hot topic uh is one way of doing it. Um, so we had influencers, usually content creators in local countries speaking like the local dialect and getting them to convert really well on Facebook ads. >> Interesting. So you'd find micro influencers, but you wouldn't have them actually post their content organically. You would just pay them to read a script and then you'd use that as an ad. >> Yeah, exactly. So um and and it became got to the point where it was so uh we couldn't predict the videos that were going to win. Um, it was just a combination of trust that they are going to come up with, you know, how influencers are, they come up with the wildest videos of like babies crying in the background, bad uh lighting, and those were always the videos that seem to catch and work. >> How much revenue was Reflectly making at its peak? >> Uh, app its peak was probably doing three 34 million AR. >> Okay. Wow. >> We were spending the exact same effectively. >> So, net net we were we weren't making massive progress. Um the charts look great but we were spending a lot of money to maintain that level. >> Interesting. Were you going for an exit because you sold the company eventually? Like were you okay with the kind of like the break even profitability or did you want to get to like profit eventually? >> Yeah. Well, it's a it's a really good question. It opens up a whole whole line of discussion. Um so it was around 2020. We were hitting these numbers. as we were growing really fast and we had all these uh different investors who are curious and interested in kind of scaling that and focusing on becoming like the next calm or the next headsp space. Um but to be honest we didn't quite believe it ourselves. I think co was about to start was happening was sort of around that time. Um and we didn't know how reliable Facebook ads were going to be. iOS 14 just came in so the tracking got worse. So the ability to just scale it to 10 20 30 40 50 million AR just didn't seem realistic. And I think that's kind of a case study of how we've been over the years trying to do what we think is realistically the best idea. And what that led to was we had another option. So we were able to acquire a habit app called Done. It's now called Do Habit. And we acquired that and it came with a portfolio of extra apps as well. Yeah. So we we acquire we acquired this one. It came with another five or six apps kind of like as a bundle. And what was really great about this is we paid uh a pretty good price for it, but it was quite undermonetized. Um there was room for growth. We knew that there was improvement in like pay walls and inapp subscriptions that we could make. And so we we acquired the app and then within sort of 12 to 18 months we made our money back. And then we thought, well, if we were going to spend the same amount of money on adverts, it's less reliable that we're going to make that same amount of money back. and we still own the habit tracker or the mobile app asset and we own all the user base and the tech as well that we can sell on afterwards if we want to. So we kind of thought maybe there's an opportunity here to build a portfolio to build a a roll up of apps and to be honest that's what we did. So for the next 5 years 2020 to 2025 roughly we just went at it. We we acquired another 30 35 apps in total and we built that portfolio. Wow, that's a lot of apps. And you had around like 50 million downloads total for all the apps combined. >> Yeah, probably more to be honest. I haven't really kept count. Um, but yeah, we we were big in driving a lot of downloads specifically through Tik Tok over the years. We had a, you know, really large content creator army that we housed, built inhouse, effectively created our own kind of university teaching them how to make good ads, good content for us. Mhm. >> Um and then we were able to get crazy amount of downloads during our peak seasons, peak periods for our portfolio of apps in you know January, February time. Um and that the amount of downloads we're able to get from these Tik Tok based videos were was quite crazy at the time. >> Okay. So you said the magic were at Tik Tok. So we're going to get into that. But right before that, I was curious about the Facebook ad arbitrage you were mentioning because it sounds like at the time, what year was that? You said 2018. >> Between 2018 and 2020. Yeah. >> Yeah. So 2018 to 2020, it seems like there was still sort of like a ad arbitrage with micro influencers and like UGC in paid ads because I guess like brands just weren't really doing that yet with um putting micro influencer UGC and like authentic feeling testimonials in Facebook ads. So were you getting like underpriced clicks and things like that? And you said it got to like 2 or 3 million AR and then it was break even. But were you profitable leading up to that like before you got to that like bigger revenue? I remember. >> Yeah. So we were profitable um before we started fully scaling and then through 2018 to 2020. Darius, who's the CMO at the time, he really uh drove the I guess the the UGC playbook in the really early days when Facebook was kind of like Tik Tok where there was such an arbitrage of no one's making these oddlooking, not so great UGC videos. Um, but they were converting like crazy because all the other big companies and advertisers were doing polished graphic ads at the time. Then that became the strategy that kind of really rose reflectly to the fame that it that it got to in the industry. >> So it seems like over time like you know and now you got into Tik Tok you know organic UGC. So it seems like the authenticity level of advertising and marketing just keeps going up and up over the years and you you guys like continue to stay ahead of it. So yeah talk to me about the the Tik Tok marketing. What was the strategy? Yeah. So it was it was basically an evolution of the Facebook strategy from 2018 to 2020 2021. Tik Tok was new. It was um you know open season. There wasn't much competition. Tik Tok ad platform was also kind of really driving you to use their ads platform tools and products. So they were incentivizing uh your ad spend to go even further. So we just dove on that and just kept building up a real creator army in house because we worked for like a lot of agencies over the years but no one then no one could really crack it internally uh for us. So we just thought why don't we just do it ourselves. So we reached out to hundreds of content creators built an in-house uh automated system that basically took a content creator from knowing about us right the way through to being able to make a video for us that converted. And we taught them every step of the way. And we automated every step of the way from interview to concept or brief that we sent to them right the way up to video that they would make, editing, going back and forth, invoicing, payments. We did the whole thing in house. And that allowed us to get to a point where, you know, let's say we had 20 apps that we were spending ads on, we could allocate certain amount of content, maybe thousands of videos um across the portfolio in a in as profitable a way as we could based off of the metrics that was coming off the back of the the ads that were being created. Do you have any of the like videos or posts still up on Tik Tok? >> Yeah. So, if you go to Tik Tok account, so uh type in do.habits and it'll be that one. And then we have another one which is growth bundle. They're all relatively the same, but if you scroll down here, it's basically goes on forever. Um it's just constant videos. Um all the same style, all the same concept with dozens of different content creators. And are you just posting all these organically or are these uh like becoming [music] ads? >> Yeah, so it was a combination. So we would post uh all of the videos organically on our own channels. Um and then if they picked up any organic traction, then we would boost them a bit more with our ad spends. And then if they really took off, we would spark ad the video to the actual content creators account. So we were effectively using four or five different ways to push the same video if it caught traction. I see. So, first you would post it organically on your own brand account and then if it started to pick up, you would start boosting it with ads. Like how much engagement does it need to have before you start boosting >> anything? You know, even if it's got like sort of 10K views. Um because obviously you're in that sort of jail period of 0 to 300 views and then once it starts breaking out into like 5,000 to 10,000 views, you see you think I've got I've got something here. there's a little bit of something special that this might be able to scale. Um, so anything crazy that you can do in the first second, you know, you take it to to drive downloads. >> So, going back to the ad scaling strategy, so you would first, you know, post organically, then you would increase the spend until you get a winner, then you would replicate the winner across creators. So, when you're increasing spend, do you start it off with a certain amount and then increase it um every day or how do you actually increase the spend on on the ad? >> Yeah, so it depends on the season and for the category of apps. So, let's talk about, you know, our biggest season, which is usually the runup to New Year's Eve or around sort of this time. Uh, you know, all the everyone trying to have like new resolutions and everything. Um, so how we would operate it, we we would do a very basic sort of campaign scaling structure. We would have a level one campaign. Basically, every video would go in as like a separate ad set and we would test each video with, you know, $10 to $20. Every video effectively gets a fair whack at hitting the target metrics at that level one level. if we see after one or two days, so maybe 20 to $40 of spend on that one video has shown promise or we just shut it off really early after $5 or $10 spend because we know where it's going. Um, if it then qualifies, it effectively graduates into a level two campaign. And in that level two campaign, it's adets again or or a CBO campaign. You can kind of run both both from parallel. Um, and this is less amount of videos but higher amount of spend. So you might be just having an ad set with four or five videos and 100 to 200 maybe even $500 um in that level two campaign. And again, Tik Tok is testing these videos now at a new level at new scale of spend trying to hit your same lower down the funnel metrics that you're targeting or top ofunnel like downloads. Eventually one or two, you know, rise to the top. Um and these become like your your level three campaigns or almost like your evergreen videos that just will take 90% of your ad spend. But you don't you don't turn off your level twos or your level ones if they're still working. >> So because once the campaign is moving and you know Tik Tok has learned that this video works well with this audience and you keep getting the results, there's no point turning it off. >> So you might get to a point where you just have the same video running at level one, level two, and level three just at different scale spans. That was effectively the model. Very simple. Again, we were a really small team. There was basically me, a media buyer, and a head of content to manage all the creators. So the simpler the better. That sounds like a lot of creators though because you you say that you would put all the ads in in one ad set and spend $20 each and then only the ones that work you would graduate to level two and then only the ones that work there you graduate to level three. So you must start with a lot of ads to begin with. But in order for it to even reach level one, you said it has to get 10,000 views organically, right? >> Yes. Well, it depends. So, when you're running uh ads in peak season, peak periods for like hour apps, that period is just so good that the videos are going to get lots of views anyway. You can go launch them all straight into level one, run them that way, or you can just do bit of both, where you can push them organically first if you don't have as much money in lower, quieter periods of the year, and then if they do work, then you boost them that way. So you you wanna you want to just put a ton of ad creatives in with you know 10 $20 $30 a day and [music] we know which which costs a little bit of money you're like wasting $20 if the ad doesn't work out. Um because with the health and fitness category and the productivity category of mobile apps, like the first week of January is effectively the Super Bowl, the blurber back Friday of results where you just have so many market tailwind wins with you that effectively your average price to acquire a download, let's say, is half for than what it is throughout the rest of the year, maybe more. So, we would spend effectively like 75% of our ad budget within the first month of the year. Um, the rest of the time we were just testing and seeing what creatives we could learn over the years to then run again back in January. >> Interesting. So like what is the deal structure in the beginning? Like I I like if they're if they're really viral and you're spark adding that is probably changes the deal structure, but in the beginning are you just like paying per video? >> Yes. So we had a flat rate per video. um that flat rate per video went up uh depending on how many viral videos or good videos they made for us. So, the more reliable they were at making viral content, the more we would pay them. At the time, we did have some bonus uh additional prices that we added on, but I know the game has changed a little bit now where people are now just only paying for performance-based only like CPM models. Uh which I I do understand. Um, I think content creators just it can take an hour or two sometimes for these content creators to make the videos. So, sometimes giving them the money to make the video upfront, you know, they made the video than you pay them, but you pay them a fixed fee for that video. And then you incentivize them to make better videos by giving them a bonus or or a raise, let's call it, the more better videos they make for you. kept more loyalty and kept people with us long term uh because they feel like they're getting paid for their their work as [snorts] opposed to hoping they get paid if the video works. And you know, if they're not super qualified, they're not the best content creators in the world, they don't get the highest fee for their single video. But if they're way more qualified and they have experience, they've been doing it for a while, they get a higher cost per video because we can guarantee that it's more likely to create a return for us as well. >> Makes sense. What's the like baseline starting out per video fee that you'd recommend? >> So, I think it's somewhere in the range of like $30 to $40 uh for like the lower tier and then it can go upwards to 80, 90, $100 for like more reliable uh content videos that being made. >> Mhm. And then would you give bonuses based on uh the ad performance or like the initial organic performance? >> A bit of both. I think we would give like a, you know, a flat fee. If it get hits a certain amount of views, like 50k or 100k views or more, they would just get like a flat rate. And then if the video really took off with ads, we kind of already know how much money that video made for us. So, we would throw them, you know, couple hundred extra dollars, $500, $1,000 maybe if like it really started working because you want to keep the content creator on your side. You want to keep them energized to work with you. and you know they've created an amazing video for you so you should do that for them as well. >> Yeah, totally. So there's a very uh sim similar road map that a lot of these uh health and fitness and mindfulness and these kind of apps kind of move along which is you effectively hit you go as far as you can where you eventually sort of hit a ceiling or the bite point of where ads make sense and your growth makes sense against like organic performance and you can either a try and raise a bunch of money and just try squeeze it harder but not as profitably or you try to create a whole new revenue line which is moving to B2B cuz if you a B2B contract. Uh, you know, it could be a couple of hundred,000. Um, and then that could be over a three, four, five year time horizon because a lot of these B2B corporation contracts are like once you you're past the KYC and, you know, accounting and you they they've approved you and you've got through the all the stakeholders, uh, you're it you're locked in and then that can be a 5year contract, which is a lot more than trying to get one person in for like an annual subscription all the time. >> Um, it is a longer lead time. It can take six to 12 months to get one contract, but one contract could be, you know, a quarter of your revenue uh in the year if played well. And you do have to build a bit more technology to make it more relatable and custom for these larger could be insurance companies, health companies, accounting firms, like whoever needs these these sort of services. But then eventually you realize like if if I can if I have a consistent model of converting these B2B leads longterm, it's probably less stressful and I make more money and I deal with less people. You know, you're just kind of dealing with like the the main stakeholders of of of the B2B customer, but it is a there is a windup time of like maybe 12 to 18 months to get going. >> It's a whole different game, but it's pretty wild. Like six figure, fiveyear contracts is like pretty crazy. Yeah. What do the companies look for in apps? >> A lot of them are trying to make sure that there is a uh a clear sort of ROI on you know if we provide this amount of subscriptions. So if you're a company of you know 10,000 employees and you have a prepackaged subscription for the mindfulness app uh you know there's a huge discount on the yearly subscription that you're giving everybody. But if you can then track the performance of let's so for example in the mindfulness app we have like a stress test and people do a stress test before and then they do a stress test at different periods throughout the year and if the overall company can see that they have paid x amount of money to create a 10 20 30% decrease in the average stress levels of people in the company that you can manifest itself into um healthier company a more positive looking company that creates more revenue as well. They're really looking for can we really see the the data from when we first start it to a year two years down the line and where is our company mindset at for example with this product in that time frame and that's hopefully our app's job to to solve that problem for them. >> Yeah, I remember when I was working in corporate they would give like a stipen like a yearly stipen and they would give you like 60% off or something like that to anything that was health related. So it seems like these companies just want their employees to be healthy and not get burnt out. >> Yeah. And you know I think with us now working from home after co like all these different layers. Um people you know with AI and everything like that as well like people's level of stress is is is evolving. It's changing not maybe what they used to be. So companies are trying to adapt more digital solutions as well to provide that to their employees. Um my day-to-day was just consumed by looking across all these different data platforms. Let's say I was going to App Store Connect, Google Play, Revenue Cat, Ads Managers, Facebook, Tik Tok, all these different platforms. And I was taking all that information, putting it into maybe like a spreadsheet or into a database. And I trying to figure out like what is the next steps here? Uh what should I do? There's so much so much data. Oh, so much so much noise. Where is the signal? And so we decided to build float. So flo 1.0 takes all that data, puts it into one location. Um and then you ask any question and you get insights and opport growth opportunities on what to do next. And what's great about that is flow 2.0 O will take all of those opportunities and we are creating AI employees for your mobile app. So think ASO agent, ASA agent, monitoring agent, forecasting agent. We will create these different employees that will do the operational load that it takes to run your mobile app. >> I like this phrasing here. It's like like chat GBT, but for apps, you're just kind of like yeah, anything you could think of to improve uh or analyze. You're just you can you can use a chat interface and just it'll you know it's like connected to all your tools. Because because I think the future is we don't think there's not a world where AI agents are not in your mobile app doing work for you. I think if you just look at the way the market is going, way AI is going, it's going to be like connecting Google Analytics to your website. You're going to connect Flo to your mobile app and then in the background while you sleep, it's just going to grow your app. It's going to find problems. It's going to make sure that they're fixed. It's going to price perfectly in 180 countries. It's going to adapt all of your custom product pages instantly. It's going to do your ASO across all these places. You know, it's just going to operate the whole thing. And I think this is the next evolution of mobile apps. ## [12/28] We can explain how to test & experiment with paywalls in less than 60 seconds #ios #appmarketing
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfzjKd7ydbI
Words: 230

as a product one of super Wall's core philosophies is that it should be easy for anyone to test pay walls I'm going to show you an example of that right here so I've got a caffeine tracking app and I've set up a campaign let's go ahead and take a look at it I've got two pay walls right now 50% of users will get the one on the left 50% of users should get the one on the right I'll go ahead and run my app here with super walls SDK integrated and I'll go ahead and take a pro action which for us is logging caffeine since I'm not pro I'll get a pay wall and there we go looks like I've got this one over here on the left now let's imagine this one on the right is performing a lot better we really want to double down on that one for this campaign well you can do that without any app update we'll just say 0% of people should get this one 100% of people should get that pay wall now when I run the app again we should see that I'm going to get the new pay wall the one on the right so we'll go ahead and do that take a pro action and sure enough I've got the new pay wall That's

So when they finally see a less edited video that's a horizontal format and it's just, you know, a minute 30 seconds of someone just talking about their lives, the people realize that, okay, this is something different and this might be something that I want to follow along.
