Like I feel like a lot of like enterprise sales people like understand this concept of like oh you got to give your clients gifts and stuff but I feel like that whole tactic is amplified by social media >> and it's like well documented in like psychology right so I study decision science so something we talk about a lot is social proof and if one person post about it everyone's just going to follow along for example when I did the series Hampton's campaign I had a bunch of interns race for a spot in the TV show and you know I I don't think students really like to post on LinkedIn but once I had like one or two people posting about it everyone became really comfortable posting about it too. So then like two days we had over a hundred interns post a banner writing a whole paragraph about um how excited they are to be part of this journey like what entrepreneurship means to them. >> Yeah, LinkedIn is so unsaturated. I feel like people love to make fun of LinkedIn, but if people are making fun of the content on a platform, that's a good thing. Like that means that the content is bad, so you can just make good content and stand out on the platform. >> I think LinkedIn is such a undervalued channel for students at least. I think this summer we've definitely seen a lot of students learning to take advantage of it, but it's still relatively uncharted territories and I think it's so beneficial to just start building a brand on LinkedIn. I would say the highest value followers you can have are probably LinkedIn followers. >> That makes sense. I mean, that's where the money is. You know, it's valuable. It's worth learning. This kind of reminds me of Monad. If you look into this, they release these like cards and you have to claim it with your Twitter account, but not everyone has one. So, then you have to get an invite from someone who nominates you. Was there an element to that with this as well where you have to get an invite or did you like hand select the interns? >> We hand selected them. We made a LinkedIn post about it and a LinkedIn job and we had over I would say maybe 2,500 applications. >> Oh wow. >> And I just personally texted a lot of them inviting them to join the series race. >> So initially it was 12, but then there's just so many applications that you just did 100. Is that like what >> No, no, no. So, the show did only have 12 interns. But in my head, I was like, that would be such a waste to just pick 12 people and just continue on with it. So, why don't we make it a little competition, right? Like, use all the channels that you can have. We had a bunch of people sign up for it. I think we had 150 people join the race to the Hamptons and then one of the final challenges for the race was to invite as many people as you can. The first place person actually invited 120 people in one day. I just thought like just use all the opportunities you can get to increase exposure and that's just through being a bit creative with it. >> Let's reverse it and like actually what would your parting words be to startup founders that want to get good at social media or find a cracked college student who's good at social media. >> When looking for them, just look at the potential, right? See their ability to turn a boring topic into an engaging story, right? like they don't have to have a million followers right off the bat because if they have the skills to tell a story, they're going to be able to bring in the attention and cult following that you need. >> I think that's a common question that I get a lot from founders actually. It's like how do you manage a content person? Are you supposed to be prescriptive so that you know that the content is actually and the marketing is actually getting results? Do you have KPIs? You have metrics or do you just let them do their own thing and sort of outsource the creativity? What's your perspective on that? Like is there a middle ground or is it one or the other? >> I think it depends on the creator. Like if they're like a seasoned creator, right? Like they've built accounts from the ground up before. I think you just got to trust them, right? Cuz the more you prescribe them like a formula, the more you prescribe them things to do, the less creative they feel. Like creative burnout is very real, especially for content creators because it's quite hard to milk out so many stories from a singular concept, right? So if you put more pressure on them, they're not going to be able to execute as well as they're able to. It's just like virality is a very interesting thing, right? It's part strategy, part luck, right? So at least in my perspective, I think the KPIs that you can set would be like they're going to have to be more qualitative than quantitative because you can't set like a okay, this particular video has to get a million likes. No one can ever guarantee that. Even a content creator with a million followers, right? But what you can say is like okay video has to be able to talk about the brand identity of this company and the information that users take away from it should be XYZ and then from there you guys work together to build the quality of the videos. You can only really get your quantitative KPIs once you have some data points. >> That makes sense. So kind of like have your marketing person understand what the goals are and like who the user is, who the market is, >> and then from there kind of just let them let them cook. >> Yeah. Basically, let them cook. You got to trust them. You got to trust them. >> Okay. Thanks so much. This is really great. I learned a lot. >> Thank you. >> If you like that episode, this is the Super Wall podcast. It's a mobile apps podcast about growth tactics and distribution hacks. So, there's more episodes on this channel if you want to check them

## [15/28] Our App Makes $30K/Month Profit Using This Simple Strategy (copy us)
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PdudtXwEsOQ
Duration: 65:52
Words: 13,339

Today I had the pleasure of talking with Alejandro and Mario, the founders behind Pushcroll, an app that's generating $30,000 in pure profit every month through completely organic marketing. >> This app made $30,000 in profits last month. >> They've cracked the code on viral Tik Tok content, built a 4,000 person Discord community that actively shapes their product, and got an insanely high 10% viewto conversion rate on a single video. >> The download rate from this video probably like 10%. We got like 20,000 downloads from this video. >> But here's the amazing thing that makes their story completely different. They didn't even start with the product. Alejandro pre-validated the idea with a single Tik Tok video about an app that didn't even exist yet. When it went viral, he found Mario on YC co-founder matching and they built the MVP in just 2 weeks. The way they've built this app is an absolute masterclass in growing a consumer app as lean as possible. They turn Discord feedback into product features within days. They've AB tested everything from onboarding flows to pay wall designs and they've been able to develop a repeatable organic content system that consistently generates them millions of views. And today they're breaking down their entire growth playbook and they're showing us number one the exact frameworks they used to design their onboarding based on Alex Hermosy's value equation. Number two, why their European audience converts completely differently than their US users. And number three, how they're using ManyHat automation to boost engagement by 10x. And if that all wasn't enough, they even show us their Figma files, walk us through their actual SuperWell dashboard, and reveal these specific mentors they paid to completely transform their conversion rates. I'm your host, Joseph Choy, and this interview is brought to you by Superwall, the all-in-one platform for paywall management and revenue analytics for your mobile apps. Let's get into it. How much money does this app make? >> So, this app made $30,000 in profit last month. >> That's awesome. Yeah, a lot of people like to share revenue numbers, but you guys are just like pure profit because you're doing organic. How did you grow to this number? >> Well, it was a a roller coaster and we we did lose a lot of money first and then we we you know, we tried a bunch of things. So, I was trying to validate a bunch of different ideas. The idea that blew up was this idea. And let me quickly show the video. Actually, >> you could stop your doom scrolling addiction by doing 20 push-ups. There's this AI thing that can actually track how many push-ups you do. Now, if you pair that with a social media blocker, now your doom scroll doesn't start until you did like 20 push-ups. Just slap your phone against the wall and once it detects 20 push-ups, you get 20 minutes of screen time. So, basically, no push-ups, no scrolling. Should I build this? Let me know in the comments. I post every day. See you tomorrow. And then pretty much this randomly blew up and you know many people just wanted to see me build this and and then I I went on YC co-founder match and I met Mario and he just happened to already build a screen time app and we just started building this and we just started building an MVP and we made a launch video as well. I think the the key with with roll was like so I was already building a a screen time app and then like I I did it sort of the wrong way. I first started with like building the product and so on before really figuring out how to sell it and then I went to marketing and I hit a wall. It was super hard to like try to market something that was not really made for it, you know. But with push roll like Alejandra was already like sort of starting with marketing, right? Like he he didn't even have the app. he built a video and then that already got a lot of attention. It's like when when we have a feature idea, you would, you know, do a UXR, you do user experience research where you'd first just create very simple screens and then show people and then just get their qualitative feedback on which one they liked more or do you like this or do you not like this and then only once it passes that then you can go on to ship it to a certain small percentage of users and then you seed the the data. It's this over-the-shoulder um you know, in the wild like what is this guy doing? And you know, this sort of creates a lot of curiosity because you you feel like you're actually there with this person that's that's recording me and you also want to know what is this guy doing? Like why is he putting his phone on the pavement and doing push-ups in the middle of the night and and then also this this caption, right? Bro is doing push-ups to unlock Instagram and a skull emoji and it's a female AI voice. and you're like, "Wait, is this a real person that's saying this?" Right? It it feels a bit uncanny. Like, there's so many factors that go into this hook, but the point is the hook has to has to be a banger. If the hook is not like a banger, the the video is not going to work. Like, because you're you you're gonna have so many people just skipping the reel, right? They're not even gonna know what the content of the video is going to be, right? The hook has to be amazing. And and really that's that's the biggest indicator of a v virality of a video. See if you have a good hook, right? We cannot really talk about the insights results we had because we just started this. I guess like we can talk about like the things that apply to everyone. So, so pretty much it's very important that the UTC creators warm their accounts properly. So like three to four days of engaging with the algorithm, you know, following people you want to create posts that are not related to the company. If you immediately start promoting the app, the Tik Tok algorithm is gonna they might like shadowban you. So you want to like post three to four posts, you know, in the general, you know, niche, for example, in our case is how many push-ups can you do like like stuff like that, right? And then you start slowly promoting the app. So that's definitely something that applies to everyone. Besides that, I would always recommend like don't go cheap on, you know, your first four or like five creators. You want a solid backbone, right? If you pay them $400 per month, it's going to show like you won't get the quality. And versus like $1,000, you most likely will will get a lot higher quality videos and it's more likely that that you're going to go viral. >> That's the philosophy we we we sort of use. There's also the philosophy of, you know, mass creation, which in some cases it works and then you can even use AI. But I think we tried it and in our case, you know, investing more into quality is always a better option for us. >> If someone's watching and they want to open up 30K a month organic channel in addition to whatever they're doing right now, what would you say is the first thing that you would do? Because you've done influencer, you've done organic, you've done it with many chat. What do you think is the first thing that someone should do if they're if they have an app already and they're trying to get organic success like you guys have? uh first validate your idea and find something that is inherently viral. If your app is not viral, you can have the best video ever. It's not going to go viral. The video doesn't even have to be good, right? We can make a video about the concept itself even and it's going to go viral because it's inherently such a viral concept. And number two is find videos of your competitors and just copy. Like don't reinvent the wheel of course like don't copy one to one. You want to look at the hooks, specifically the hooks, and you want to dissect why the hook worked. In our case, we we copied this from from another competitor. And we just adapted it slightly. We even improved it a little bit, and it worked. If you see something works in this niche, you can apply it as well to your own niche. And in terms of like where to start, I think first of all, you're not going to have a lot of money when you're starting most likely. So, organic is a really nice way to get some initial views. But then also like when you're trying to do UGC, you don't want to give like the UGC creator like full flexibility on what what you want to do. That's more like influencer, right? So in any case, you want to do organic for sure because if you see a a format that's going viral organically, then that's when you decide, all right, let's do GGC with it to scale it up. Like UGC is more like for scaling from my point of view. Maybe influencers for like more like reach or also some sort of GGC. But organic is also like always a nice way to validate ideas and and to like be in there like knowing knowing everything. >> The most profitable thing you can do is really find a winning format. And in our case that yeah, we found it and we just rinse and repeat until it doesn't work. And ideally you have three to four different formats because if you do the same format it's going to fatigue at some point. That's really like the most profitable thing you can do yourself. And it's also gonna help with with influencers. is going to help with right UGC and especially like ads right for ads you always want to keep creating creatives and right because you want to run all the ads simultaneously and you want the the meta algorithm to optimize >> any tricks or habits to find those winning formats faster >> focus purely on the hook and everything else like 80% of your energy should go into the hook like the hook is so important like I cannot underestimate how important the hook is and you want to look specifically at the skip rate. You know, if you see it's a 30% skip rate, then you know find a different format, iterate on it until your skip rate is around 18% more or less and then you have a you have a winning hook. I would recommend like as well to to join, you know, these creatormies because they they can like break it down a lot better than I can. For example, a really good one is um Mino Lee. ## [16/28] The App Marketing Strategy No One Talks About
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SyVVLbMgAXc
Duration: 57:27
Words: 10,802

What if the secret to organically growing an app wasn't making content, but making comments instead? And what if you could do it at a scale that seems virtually impossible? You got 7,000 clicks on the campaign. And how many comments did that did that take? >> I believe around 300,000 maybe. Yeah, I I guess around that. >> You did not hear that wrong. 300,000 Instagram comments from one campaign. The crazy thing is this isn't a team of 100 virtual assistants. This is two guys, Nick and Ivan, and an army of automated phones. >> We automated a bunch of physical devices, and we did our own version of Android that can load and unload the ROM of the whole device. So, each account will have basically its own unique phone. >> After 8 years of working together, from running Minecraft servers to building a consumer app for flights, they stumbled upon a new way to grow. and they realize that getting app users on social media is a lot like B2B sales. This this kind of reminds me of cold email a little bit where people are warming up these inboxes and if you want to send, you know, 50,000 cold emails, you have to set up dozens of inboxes and spread the emails across all of these inboxes. They're literally applying the science of cold email to the art of Instagram comments. But the part that blew my mind is that the comments that work best aren't spammy or super subversive or anything like that. They're just straight up transparent. [music] >> When you test these things, you find things that work surprisingly good. So, you might think that being upfront about this being your own app, your own company, and so on would, you know, harm your engagement, but it does the opposite often. So, people like it. >> And with just 60 phones, they're already generating massive results, but they're not stopping. They're scaling to a,000 devices which would be able to post 21 million comments a month. >> What we can do with 1,000 devices. So in one month that's almost 1.5 million videos and 21 million comments. So just just as a you know scale perspective that's like replying to every single person on Mr. Beast reels on Instagram within like a month. >> In this episode, Nick and Ivan pull back the curtain on the future of distribution. The arts of building a technical moat that your competitors can't copy. how to write comments that actually convert with a 15% click-through rate from profile to link and how they're turning this underground agency into a platform to let anyone command an army of automated social media agents. This is the playbook for distribution using a channel you might not have thought of before at a scale you've definitely never seen before. Let's get into it. This is the Superall podcast and I'm Joseph Choy, founder of Consumer [music] Club. the members in the consumer club Discord and the founders I interview on the pod build apps at a median of about a million dollars ARR. In my conversations with dozens of these founders every week, one thing I've noticed is most of them AB test their payw walls to increase their conversion rates and make more money. Now, most people know that one of the best ways to AB test payw walls is Superwall. But one thing you might not know is Superwal has a lot of data on the thousands of apps that use their payw walls. So recently they actually put together a tool that takes 422 profitable paywall experiments and put those into a paywall experiment generator where you can upload a screenshot of your own payw wall and it'll give you an experiment idea to increase your revenue. You can use it for free at paywallexperiments.com. All right, let's get into the podcast. Most people think of app growth through either organic or ads. You're either posting content or you're putting content in ads and people see the content in the ads. But for you guys, you're posting comments on other people's content. So there's other content that's going viral or is relevant to a niche and then you're posting comments and getting users through that. Can you just explain how that works and how you got started figuring this out? >> Yes. So the way it works is uh we create accounts uh we brand them uh we set them up configure them uh and uh the goal is to make the real speed uh of their of these accounts show the trending content in the niche that we want to target. So we don't want to target random content. We want to specifically find like trending viral videos uh or videos that have potential to go viral. So that's why we can't just rely on search. we need to specifically set up the for you page feed in a right way. And uh the way it works is uh we we warm up the accounts using AI filters. So uh we basically set up this uh prompts the system that analyzes the videos what's going on in them and uh it uh finds the videos that are the right fit and we engage with these videos. We skip the videos that we want don't want to engage with. Uh the accounts you can see they are u branded to look like official sub pages for interns of the company that we promote. So if it's an app then that's uh just an account that represents this app and uh yeah the bio fits and uh the link and bio is just the app store. So simple uh on this side. So like I said if if the content is the right fit we engage with it. If it's not we skip it. uh the comments are analyzed to fi 2 so that we see if there's the potential to reply to people and if there's the potential potential to comment on the video if there are tons and tons of uh comments that are like irrelevant then people won't read the comment section so we need to skip it and uh if people are already highly engaged in this comment section then it's probably can be a good idea to also reply there so we see the comments that are a fit and those that are and obviously we skip those that are not relevant and we focus on those that are so comments can look in a lot of ways. There's always multiple sub campaigns to test what works best. There are a ton of approaches that you can take. So, uh one of them for example is we can answer the specific question that people ask in the comment section. The questions are related to the video that is that we target and uh yeah we just target to this uh we just answer this uh questions and then only at the end of the comment we add some sort of CDA to you know check out our page. Uh other option could be instead to ask a question. So our accounts also want to engage in a conversation. So we ask questions to people and then we for example name drop the app. So yeah can be a lot of ways that it can look like uh the third option is for example the story and doesn't even include any kind of call to action but has some sort of engagement starter like mentioning something that is going on on some certain app or even our pages everywhere but like doesn't ask for anything. It just makes people wonder uh and wants to check out our page. Uh so yeah, we see we don't we don't reply to everyone. We don't want to target people who just say thank you, thanks for the video and so on. We only target people who actively engage, who ask questions or state their opinions and so on. So yeah, and comments and replies are basically UGC and text form. So the same principles that apply to UGC videos, they apply to comments and replies. For example, in this uh in this uh comment, we specifically say that uh you know some sort of story and that we use this specific app for uh our exercises. And this naturally makes people wonder what what kind of app are you talking about like what what's this app? And some people will ask it inside our replies and some people will just go straight to profile and go from there. Yeah. Another example is like I said uh positioning our accounts as you know uh workers of this brand, workers of this app or friends of founders. of like founders themselves and so we provide some sort of value first and then mention something about the app. Another option is also like UGC type thing where it's some kind of buddy that recommended the app and so our accounts are going to try it out too. >> So can you go back go back to that first screenshot example in the slide seven? >> Yep. >> Yeah. So can you explain why are these good comments like what are these doing? >> I think it comes down to two things. So obviously the comment must be context dependent. It cannot be copy paste uh you know random thing uh the straight promotion uh it needs to be context dependent. It needs to talk about what's going on in the video and what people already talking about in the comments. So the comment itself has to be of good quality. Uh for example it it starts with a story which already makes people you know it's like a hook inside the videos but the same thing applies to text. Uh and yeah in it ends with a very soft like it's not even a call to action. It's just a mention like you know saying a fact and uh yeah that that makes people engage with this content. The second part of it is not just the the comment itself is the video under which it's posted and the timing of the video. So uh if we find the videos that have viral potential and we one of the f first people to post under it uh then our comment will be on the top and it will have much more potential to you know go kind of go viral inside the comment section and if the video is already too old then there's basically no point to you know uh leave a comment there because they won't go viral. It's interesting like yeah so basically the scripts for these comments uh this one says like once I tried working out by myself thinking I was an expert just because I watched a few videos. Let's just say I ended up with all my muscles sore and spent a week in bed laughing emoji. It's wild how much I learned though. Now I use an app for my exercises. So it's like that's the soft CTA you're talking about. And so then how does that actually work? Do people then wonder like, oh, what I wonder what app they're they're using and then they ask in the reply and then you follow up again with the name of the app or are they going and clicking the profile and seeing a link in bio? >> We actually do both. Uh so sometimes people can uh just reply and we will follow up on them. It's actually something that we developed somewhat recently. Let me let's like zoom out and I want to learn about your guys like founding story. Like how did you get into >> this Instagram? Did it start with Instagram comments or was there something before? So it's it's like crazy. >> So all of these like viral Tik Toks were mostly just >> Was it kind of like a proof of concept for you guys? let's just try to go viral on Tik Tok. There was no like business behind it necessarily. >> I would say uh it was part of the business to just prove the concept that our uh automation uh system can uh run Tik Tok accounts and they can get a lot of views and also we did promotion for the like we included uh the music of our clients in these Tik Toks and uh they made for uh 1 million views. Yeah, one of the goals that we wanted to reach at at that time was to make people film their own videos uh by you know first so we use the client's music inside our video and people just uh click on the sound and click use this sound and record their own videos and so for example when we included call to actions about this specific action. So go and film out your own video uh we had like we had results from this but yeah on the business side uh it wasn't like it wasn't the best thing ever. It was more of a proof of concept than proof of the technical detail because we are not we ourselves are not a content creation team and uh this type of thing requires client to you know provide their own content or provide concepts for the content uh and so on and yeah we had to do everything our most of the things ourselves and uh yeah this this is too difficult. So that's one of the biggest reasons why we switched to comments because comments are much easier to iterate and we can just focus on you know coming up with creative ideas and developing tech. >> So that's that's an interesting nuance that I don't think many people like are going to catch. So what you just said is that you don't make the content. So when you were making Tik Toks all you did was automate the posting of the content. So can you just explain why is that necessary? Why? Like that's you said that that's your that was almost your whole business just the automation of the posting while your clients would actually make the content. So why why was that so valuable? Um or why is that so valuable to businesses? >> I would start with the fact that beside besides the uploading itself, it's also account engagement and account warm-up. So you want your accounts to not just uh post videos and leave the app. You want them to engage with the app. We want them to engage with other people and so on. And this is a lot of work like uh why why companies wouldn't do it themselves? Well, they do, but this requires hiring VAS, hiring clippers, hiring people that you need to manage most of the time. And uh these people uh even then if you were able to manage all of them, they are still people and they can't do a thousand things at once. They can't automate. They can't uh use 1,000 phones at once, most of them at least. And so yeah, this is a question of scale. This is the question of uh practicality and the question of do you want to manage a ton of people uh who often don't want to be managed and do want to do their own thing or do you want like the system that works just 24/7 uh like with very little moderation on your side. >> Okay. So it's a question of scale. When companies like when businesses like post content, they're not just posting on a single account. They're posting on how many accounts would they post on? >> Yep. I I think a lot of businesses want to do as as much as possible >> and uh the more accounts you have on one device uh the less trust you will have from the social media. I think on Tik Tok you can add somewhat close to 10 accounts per one device and the more you have the less trust you get the less views you get the less engagement you get. Basically algorithm detects that you are uh abusing it and that's it. >> So normal people can't run too many accounts. So what you're saying is the there there's there's kind of like a value chain in this whole like organic content economy where it starts with the content creation. So you make the content and then you well even before that it's like figuring out what what content to make in the first place. So content strategy and like creative research. Um then it's okay now how do I take these concepts and strategy and make a bunch of content. So that's like generative AI platforms. And then third is how do we actually post the content? Because like you just said, Tik [music] Tok and Instagram have, you know, anti-botting algorithms and they don't want you to have too many accounts on a single phone. And they definitely don't want you to have, you know, 100 accounts all posting um, you know, content all the time, every day. >> But you guys do that. Um, so what does it take to be able to do that? >> [music] >> We automated a bunch of physical devices and uh uh we did uh our own version of Android uh that can load and unload the ROM of the whole device. So each account uh will have basically its own unique phone. By this design, we can just change account uh by demand uh giving us like I like 20 accounts on Instagram and around like I think 100 or 200 accounts on Tik Tok per day per device. And uh with uh with all of that we also have our own system how to uh press buttons uh to be undetected by the algorithm. how to will basically how to interact with the phone in a way that ith will think that we are actual real humans. >> It's pretty insane. That's like the that's kind of like the core like secret sauce of this whole thing. And it's it is a real bottleneck for certain scale. Like once you crack an organic format, imagine what you do next. Well, you want to multiply it. You want to post it like five more times. >> What are you going to do? Post it five more times on like one single account? Probably not. Like if you're going to post a hundred times, you know, and it's a format that works really well, then you're probably going to need more accounts, more phones. So you guys like have that infrastructure. So um >> yeah. >> Yeah, that's really interesting. What do you think is the limitation? Like why are why are more people not doing this? >> Well, at first a lot of companies are starting to do that actually. I think UGC uh stuff is just uh starting to show up on our radars. Just a couple of years ago, there was like a few companies that did that and right now we have uh VCs investing in uh phone uh infrastructure startups and uh yeah uh quite a bunch of them actually. So I think it will be the future of content distribution in the very short uh period of time. It feels like this is a very like almost controversial topic in the I guess like app or creator economy or UGC space. Like what else are you going to spend like 6 hours a day on like there's no apps that really contest like Tik Tok, Tik Tok, Instagram, YouTube and startups seem like they're kind of fighting back and and like you said VCs are almost like funding this idea that let's just you know like these platforms have their rules because they want to protect their platforms against like people taking distribution into their own hands. And it seems like you guys are like part of that like that startup wave of like let's try to like sidestep their game almost. It's a completely new world. I think normally I on this channel I I talk to a lot of um founders that are doing UGC sort of by the book, but something something that not a lot of people think about is UGC organic is inherently competitive to to Tik Tok's interest. like they don't want you to go viral with UGC [music] and make money from it because they would rather have you spend money on ads, right? Like if you're just paying creators, Tik Tok gets none of that on a big picture. Like they're incentivized for masscaled UGC operations, they're incentivized for those to just not work, which is why they fight so hard to like uh shut down these kinds of things. So does that ever scare you guys? Like do you feel like you're up against kind of this like huge machine that's always trying to like shut you down? >> Not at all actually. It's quite uh the opposite on Instagram. Uh like only like the smallest percentage of people are creating the content. Most of the people are consuming the content. So there is uh like a giant gap between uh content creators and content consumers. So we with uh with any content that performs which is the only content that works in terms of uh advertisement in terms of UGC uh that does perform you are helping the social media app actually you're uh filling this endless well you're filling the void uh of uh missing content for people to consume. Social media apps are craving people that create content, great content. And uh if we distribute content that doesn't perform, that doesn't doesn't get any views, doesn't get any engagement, then well, nobody's afraid of that. Why would you be? Uh nobody's going to see it. Uh it doesn't harm anyone. So yeah, only the content that doesn't that does perform shows up on the feed. And if it if it shows up in the feed, it uh gets social media engagement up uh therefore we are helping the social medias. >> Yeah. >> Yeah. Uh I would also add to it that it it's really even more relevant in like underserved niches like there are categories of content that not that many people create but people want to consume. And so if like Instagram and Facebook, they want to like have everyone on their platform that they would need to serve their interests. And then again uh for their own ads, they need to be able to target people who express interests in certain things. And why wouldn't they would like to do it from within their platform? when people consume like things inside the categories that they want to consume, uh the meta would be able to target them and show them ads in this specific niche. So, that's a win-win. >> So, when you reach out to creators and you're about to invest into organic social and maybe boosting those videos with paid ads, you don't want to just let the creators do whatever they want. Most of the app founders I talked to on this channel basically have the same content philosophy. The videos need to go viral but also convert and promote an app and ideally are also repeatable. And those formats are like gems and really hard to find. That's why Tik Tok can sometimes feel like a lottery system. Um, this format is several years old. So, this is kind of like the the classic like influencer video like, "Hey guys, today I'm going to talk to you about whatever like product." Um, so this this is still like kind of big. Um, and with an app, you kind of have to show show the product somehow. Like with e-commerce, it's really easy. You like you hold it in your hand. You can like show it on video. But with apps, it's a little bit tricky. You have to like figure out how to show it on the screen. Um, so one way is like just is just like green screen. So you can just put it behind you. Um, and then have like the talking head like green screened in front of you. Um, another way is like phone app demo. So, if you have like the you literally put the phone in front of your other phone to record the like record what's happening on the screen and show yourself using the app. Um, but talking head, I mean, this is like a couple years old. A couple of the newer things like it kind of shifted last year to to slideshows when people realized like you could just get a lot of views by doing uh Tik Tok carousels and slideshows instead of like full videos. And this is there's some alpha in this because it's so easy to make. Um so you're you're like building it public was actually it doubled as marketing for your product. Oh, maybe like the concept of agencies like I wish Yeah, let's talk about that. I wish more people understood like the concept of agencies in a new in a new underpriced distribution channel. Like whenever there's a new underpriced distribution channel, it's underpriced because there's not very many marketers who've mastered the channel. And everyone comes to me and they're like, "Who's the best organic expert, you know?" And I'm like, "There are none." They're like, "The ones that are the that are the best are the founders because they're the ones who are the most obsessed and they're most financially incentivized to figure out the channel." There's not going to be that many marketers that are willing to just work for you on retainer when they're one of five people in the whole world who know how to do this stuff. So totally really think that you need like with underpriced distribution you kind of have to understand it yourself. Um then you can hire someone to um uh to take over the the thing that you figured out. Totally. Okay. That's really really interesting. I would approach them with caution and just like I think there's certain experts and service providers and agencies that do do a good job, but I feel like their lifespan is no more than like like no more than 6 months because the either they take on too many clients and then there's the service quality just goes down because there's just too many people to to take care of. um or they're so good that they just decide to stop doing stuff for clients and they just build their own products. ## [18/28] The Secret Behind Weirdly Viral Apps
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_a4ch3pk_U0
Duration: 44:31
Words: 8,448

App founders are using this playbook to get hundreds of thousands of downloads on their apps by hiring college students, having them make videos every single day, and going viral with actually high converting short form videos on Tik Tok. So, in this video, I talked to Canyon, the co-founder of Sideshift, a platform that has 150,000 college students looking for jobs in UGC and making these daily videos. he dropped some really good case studies where we go straight into the accounts and the formats that are getting downloads for apps right now. >> So we uh Sideshift we started running kind of this high volume organic playbook in like late February probably like four months ago. Um, previous to that we'd been, you know, doing just marketing on our own social channels, physically going in person to these college campuses and I think we're probably around like 10,000 kind of job seekers on our platform. Um, so about 10,000 users and over the past 3 to four months have kind of grown that to be now over 150,000 uh active job seekers. And it's largely been in part due to this high volume organic. probably the most cost-effective way I think for consumer founders to you know market and distribute their product. We've spent probably around 10k across the board and so you just like run the numbers on that and like a customer acquisition cost that's you know pennies is just ridiculous. And so I think, you know, as we run this playbook more too, you just get more efficient in it because you start to figure out the formats that work and you can just replicate that. And obviously they don't work forever. You know, you need to continue to iterate and experiment. Um, but it's one of those things where, you know, I think we're going to continue to double down. We actually had to turn off our funnels in like miday. We only have one, we only had one engineer at the time. And so when we had like, you know, 50,000 new kind of creators join our marketplace in the span of like a week or two, like products started breaking. Our businesses were getting like 3,000 applicants, which is like great in theory. Um, but the product wasn't really built for that. But it is one of those things where it's like as our content, you know, continues to convert and drive more users and creators to our platform, we see a direct correlation to the businesses that we work with having success um because they're getting a bigger pool to pick from on the creator side. They can make hires much quicker and they can just launch much bigger programs for, you know, a very very affordable cost. So, it's been it's been really cool to see kind of how this flow has evolved. How many views on short form videos do you think you got from the the 10K budget? >> Yeah, let me I can actually pull up and get a pretty accurate um perception of this. So >> Oh yeah, that would be cool to like see it. Yeah, we've run two campaigns and so the last one that we ran um which I would say is probably equates to like half of our views um was 16 million through it was I think a 300 post campaign um maybe maybe it was a little bit more. It might have been closer to 20 I think for whatever reason. And the dates are off, but we just found >> million views in >> Yeah. >> 30 days from 60 posts >> from from 300 posts. 300 posts. So >> 300 >> AC across the board. We had we had five creators making content, posting, most of them were posting twice a day. And I would say for the first two weeks, I think UGC is one of these things where it like it takes a lot of patience because it like some people crack it right away. They find a winning format within like week one of posting. I would say that's not standard for us. It took like two to three weeks and then as soon as we found one format, we were just doubling down on that. We had all five of our creators pumping it out like every other day basically. And you know, it was a 2 million video view video here, a 5 million view video here, you know, 100,000 video views that start to stack up. And it's like when one account starts to pick up steam, like it just is really just a flywheel that affects all the videos. You know, people are then engaging with the rest of their videos, which just kind of fuels the funnel and their account just gets pushed out into, you know, that audience that you're, you know, inevitably trying to target. And so I think it's one of those things where founders that, you know, have patience and are willing to go weeks or even months at a time without seeing, you know, extremely extraordinary results, like they get rewarded in the long run because they just continue to experiment and iterate. And so it's it's one thing that we like a with the companies that we work with try to just like alert them that like look, it doesn't work on the first try every single time. Um, sometimes it takes 300 posts before you find that winning format, but when you do, you know, you're able to just double down on that and and really just change your business. Uh, dramat some of the videos from this campaign. >> One of the things that we have really tried to lean into is just with like the job market, everything that's going on. I think it's like leaning into trends of just like the broader like macro economy as well as like trends that are happening on Tik Tok. It's like you don't need to reinvent the wheel. I mean, we see he's like getting denied from whatever jobs, leaning into the fact that he has a master's degree. Um, we can click in these slideshow formats have, you know, actually really converted a ton as well. Um, and it's just like, you know, it's subtle. It's it's not just screaming your product out. It's just, you know, subtly dropping subtly dropping it in there. Sometimes saying the product. You don't always need to lay the product, but like, you know, UGC creator side shift app. this gets a few hundred,000 views, like that just converts insanely well. >> This is a that's a perfect slideshow that got 84,000 views and you listed the name of the app on the last slide and it was like highly engaging because it's like what are you going to rate the next thing like the out of 10 format I feel like is really >> strong. Also, this guy has less than 2,000 followers. He has 1,900 followers. like >> right when he started the account he had zero followers and so like these are all you know these are fresh accounts um obviously you get it warmed up into whatever niche you know you're trying to go after but it's like as you start to like it definitely you know as we can see like if we go all the way back here you know he's been posting for a while like some of the videos it takes a while like these videos only get a 100red views like you start getting into the a thousand view range but you know you post a ton and you see no results for a while, it can start to be like very, you know, discouraging. Um, but I think, you know, just continuing to put shots on goal, it's it's one of the things that's really hard for people. I think people just tend to give up on a marketing channel and just try and go find the next best thing. Like the reality is like all these marketing channels, they're, you know, they're hard. They're hard to master and it just takes reps. It just takes practice. And I think the beauty of UGC is you can get so many more reps and so much more practice for just such a cheap cost and it just allows for so much experimentation. >> Can you go to some of the viral ones and then some of the not viral ones and like kind of describe the differences? Like what do you think do well? So for this one, like we had found this format um with one of our other creators like getting denied from a job, having a master's degree, like it's ironic in the sense that like oh my god, like even in this job market, even if you're, you know, college educated, um have gone to school, it's something that just like resonates with a lot of people. Um, and so I think something that's either extremely controversial drives a lot of engagement or something that is just extremely resonating with a large demographic of people like everyone in the comments is just talking about like how just difficult you know the job market is and you know so it's one of those things and so I think he did a good job of also too like you can see how engaging he is with these comments like that's something that just continues to spur you know additional engagement people are then responding to him and like that engagement level continues to push, you know, your videos out into into the feed. Um, and so I think that's something we try to work with our creators a lot on is like look, it doesn't just stop at the video you post. Like you need to go environment or engineer this environment in the comments that's, you know, extremely collaborative, has people asking, you know, where are people finding jobs? And that's where you can start to subtly plug in your product as well. Um because at the end of the day, you know, views are great, but it's like how do we get our product? It's like boom, like this is why I only use Sideshift. You know, people are liking that that's converting to real users. And so, I mean, we can even go down here to like an older one. Others just take more time. Um, and so it's one of those things where you kind of just got to weather the storm and, you know, wait to just find a format that, you know, resonates with people. >> That's interesting. So, what I'm curious like what instructions did you give this creator when you first hired him? Was it um did you get have some some kind of brief um showing? That would also be interesting. >> Yeah. So, I can pull up kind of an example brief. I will use one of our customers as an example. I won't go fully into the details to get rid of their secret sauce. Um, but I'll kind of give the high level. So, I think one thing that is important to touch on is like who is your company? Like what is what does your company do in your own words? Um, because I think a lot of the time people will just be like, "Hey, go download my app and like make content about it." And a lot of the time like a creator like using an app for the first time like seeing it from an outside lens like they don't necessarily know like what the core value prop of that product is like what's that viral moment that I can lean into like what problem are you solving with your audience and so I think that's one thing to touch on like one thing they did a really good job of is like adding in like Loom videos chatting through their product making it extremely you know personalized like you want to start to, you know, treat your creators like they're a part of this community. You want them to be excited to make content about your product. So, that's one thing. Um, I think as well like who's your target audience, you know, like do you have personas that they can tap into? Because at the end of the day, one of the things is like as they warm this account up, they need to make sure that it's getting pushed out into the right audience so that people are actually engaging with their content. Um, and so I think that's like one of the biggest things and one of the most important things of the brief is like who do we actually want to target? And I think some people run into the trap where they have a product that could really just be targeted at anyone and they don't focus on any specific niche and because of that the content that gets pushed out feels pretty just like bland. You know, there's nothing special to it. It doesn't feel like it's meant for anyone. And I think because of that, like it just doesn't perform that strongly. Um, another thing that's, you know, I think extremely strong, and this is something that gets built up over time. Um, if you have viral videos on your own socials, if you have people that have made content for you, like link those videos, you know, give your creators a starting point so that when they start making content, like they already have a few formats that they can run with. Obviously, you want to give your creators, you know, the creative freedom to do what they do best and experiment and find new formats for you, but if you don't give them anything, like they're kind of just starting from a disadvantage when you can kind of just prop them up a bit. Other if you have competitors um or adjacent players in your kind of, you know, community um maybe for us like we're a job platform at the end of the day for these creators. if there's like other jobesque content um that has gone viral before. Uh trying to kind of take those themes and transfer them into kind of your niche and about your company and product. Um and yeah, I think that kind of ties into this like formats from other videos. Um you know, like Sideshift, Migrate Mate were both kind of job boards in that regard. So there's a lot of similarities that you can transfer over. I think putting together hook ideas is like, you know, good but not necessary all the time. Um, I think sometimes having a few can be a good starting point, but I don't I think sometimes the challenge people run into is they just overwhelm their creators and they just throw like this 50page brief at them and it's like a like nobody wants to read that. like they're just going to open it up and see how overwhelming it is and just instead of hitting, you know, the the few key points that are actually important to learn, they'll just skip it all together because they're like, I don't want to sift through this. And so it's like how can we condense the most important information and just like give that to, you know, our creators. Um pay as well. This is usually something you'll talk about with the creators as well. We kind of recommend like a hybrid model. So $15 to $20 per video with a base retainer is is pretty common. And then we like to throw pretty generous performance bonuses as well. I think it really aligns incentives and, you know, can drive a ton of just engagement. It'll it'll, you know, incentivize them to engage with comments after they just post the video. Um, and so I think there's, you know, a lot of good that comes from this kind of hybrid model in terms of attracting quality people with that retainer and then just aligning incentives with those bonuses. So, yeah, to kind of chat through the the warm-up process, I know everyone kind of has their different views and I think there's a lot of just unknown. Um, and so I don't think anyone's necessarily right or wrong. There's, you know, different ways to do it that still work. Um, I think how we try and describe it to our creators is by just saying like put yourself in the shoes of kind of the end user. Like if I'm promoting for Sideshift, like act as if you're a broke college student that like needs a side hustle and like maybe makes content already or has, you know, done side hustles in the past and just like act as if you're one of those people and just engage with that content consistently. You need you need to act human. like these algorithms get better every single month. And so if you just like spam and interact with every single post and just like scroll very quickly, like people can tell that's not just like human behavior. You know, act as if you're actually scrolling. It's it's definitely very tedious and probably the worst part of this entire process. And so how we try and frame it to our creators is like, look, we want to have you making content with us for, you know, the next year potentially. And like the account warm-up process kind of lays the foundation for that. And so do it right the first time so that you ideally don't need to make another account and start over from scratch. And like as you build up this account like you'll have thousands and thousands of followers if if done correctly that you'll gain over the next few months. And so just take the extra you know few hours that it takes to warm it up properly. We typically do like a three to five day warm-up. I like to start my creators posting on Mondays. And so if I onboard a crew on like Wednesday, like maybe the warm-up process is a little bit longer. If I onboard them on Friday, maybe it's a little bit shorter. Um I think that stuff's a little arbitrary. I think if you just maybe take a little bit more time um on a shorter like day window, maybe you spend, you know, an extra hour warming it up, like that's one way to do it. Um and so I think there's different methodologies for it. A lot of people have like the bottom up approach. you know, you're sharing, you're commenting, you're liking, you're engaging. Um, but I think just like the bottom line is like you just need to act like a human. Um, and act like a human that's in that niche that you're actually promoting. And I think it goes a long way. Um, but yeah, like kind of like long stories, just like keep it short and sweet for the creators. like give them their your maybe list of like nuances that they need to do when setting up their account. Uh, first thing, this is the the girl he ended up hiring. Hasn't even posted a ton, but just has seen, you know, some really strong results. So, that was obviously a huge indicator. Um, second indicator is like when he actually had a conversation with her, she was extremely responsive. She was like wanting to run strategy on the account. She's like, "I have a ton of ideas that I would love to experiment with." And it's funny cuz he was like, "Anytime I would throw an idea at her to try it out, like it would perform terribly." So, I ended up just letting her run things fully. And I think that's like one of the fine lines between like giving people just enough information on kind of what your product is and who you're targeting and then letting them run free. Obviously, you know, not every creator is built the same and some people need to be you need to be a little bit more hands-on with. Um, but yeah, just like in her case alone, I think it's good to like figure out how hands-on or hands off they want to be with everything. But yeah, we can pull up how this account performed and it's just absolutely insane. Um, 40 46 posts on this campaign and doing 35 million total views. Like that's almost a million views per post, which is insane, especially for for his first crack at it. um hiring one creator and just like hitting the jackpot right away. Um I think there's a few interesting things that he noticed from this process as well. Like a insane growth in users. Um so he saw like a 10x growth in just like the amount of downloads that he was getting on a on a weekly basis which is obviously huge. Um, but what's really interesting too is before when people would go to his app, it would convert at around 5 to 10%, like let's say someone views him on the app store, um, the chance that they actually downloaded the app was like 1 in 10 or even 1 in 20, which is extremely low. And obviously for new apps that, you know, don't have a ton of ratings, don't have a ton of social proof, like people are just, you know, less likely to give them a shot. Um, and since running this organic playbook, you know, it was converting at over 50%. So, one out of every two people that actually searched him up on the app store or saw him on the app store was downloading it. And I think it just goes to show that like hearing about a product through just like an organic piece of content gives it so much more credibility that these views and these engagements, they convert at such a higher rate. And so I think it goes to show that like organic I I think is starting to become, you know, leaps and bounds more effective than even paid ads for a lot of these consumer products out there. But yeah, I mean this account was going absolutely, you know, crazy. Um, we can pull it up here and and just see. And what's funny is like one of the things that was working really well um is like he had a bunch of conceptions of like let me just show the best pieces of content of the product but like one thing let's see if I can find uh I don't know which video it was but like he was just showing she was like posting like when the AI would mess up and like the crazy like formats that it would pump out and I think that was that was pretty comical. Um, I think I don't know if we can maybe pull this one up, but like yeah, like for example, like has like a third leg sticking out and it just drove so much engagement. She was like great in the comments as well, like responding to comments like as soon as someone asks like what the app is, plugging photogenic in. Um, and so yeah, super, you know, strong results from someone that has just started it. And so he's like he's also just learned a lot about his product in itself. Like I think when you get so many more users on your product, he's been able to just create such an environment in there that has increased retention and you know just drove tons of super users that I think he wouldn't have otherwise had if he got if he didn't get that influx of users right off the bat. Um and so yeah, he's been he's been crushing. So that's been, you know, really cool to see for someone that's just kind of giving it a go at their first their first time at it. >> That's wild of 35 million views with 50 videos. It's so true. But also like when you have an ad on Tik Tok or Instagram or YouTube or anything, you automatically like it's labeled as an ad and you know it's an ad. So of course the landing page conversion is going to be lower than if the person's like actively searching for the app in the app store because there's no link to the to the app store, right? like on these any of these videos, they're like closing the Tik Tok app, going to the app store, searching it in, >> and then >> once they find the app, of course, they're not going to like like drop off at that point. Like maybe 50% do, but >> that's just like so much better than um maybe accidentally clicking the ad and then be like, "Oh, I don't want this." >> Exactly. Exactly. >> That's really cool. Um nice. That's a great case study. Can we look at the the studio as well? >> Yeah, for sure. So, yeah. So, we've been working with an app studio um Vert Ventures. They're they're promoting a couple of their apps right now. Astro is like astrology app. Haven is like a a Bible study app. And one thing that they've done a really good job of, I think both of their apps have been like top five in their category for past few weeks or they've been in and out of it, but I know they've been crushing. And one thing that they've done a great job of is finding winning formats in organic and sparking them into paid. And so I think there's like some products I think are naturally better for organic and some products are naturally better for paid. And I think they've found this good blend of the ability to drive downloads through organic and find a way to just repurpose that content for paid. And so I think it's it's definitely something that's a lot harder, you know, to learn and master. like they're wicked smart on the grow side over there and you know have a history of just doing insane stuff in terms of distribution. Um but they've just experimented with so many different formats creators from every side of the spectrum. You know they've got a few girls, a few guys working on it, bunch of different ages, tons of different formats. like we can, you know, click on this video for example and it's like talking about, you know, your your sign and how, you know, Astra helped them find their sign and stuff like that as opposed to like, you know, we've got this kid over here who's talking and just displaying a ton of astrology knowledge and, you know, plugging, you know, Astra is obviously a resource to, you know, kind of try and find this uh this information, especially if you're, you it's something that you're interested in. Um, and so it's been it's interesting to see how, you know, a lot of different apps can take a very different approach and still, you know, see great results. And I think it just comes down to, you know, that that piece of you just need to experiment and throw a ton of shots on goal and just start to figure out, you know, where your app kind of fits into the kind of distribution network and what levers you can pull on um to really just drive the biggest impact. And so I think it's it's something they've done, you know, a great job of over the past like few months and honestly over the since since they've launched. >> That's awesome. So, you're getting all these downloads from your viral Tik Toks. How do you actually turn these people into customers? You do that with payw walls with Superwall. And yeah, Consumer Club is where I talk to other app founders about these strategies every day. We talk about what's working, what's not working for viral distribution and just other ways of doing marketing uh for your apps. So check out Superwell, check out Consumer Club, back to the pod. I feel like for app studios like this where they're building multiple apps, it's a really great way to test like you see the huge numbers and it's like, oh yeah, you can scale, you can get, you know, hundreds, thousands of downloads on your app, but it seems like an actually pretty cheap way to test a market, too. like if if someone has an app and they're trying to test this marketing channel with short form Tik Tok or short form organic, what what strategy have you seen work well for just doing kind of like lowbudget tests and validating uh app ideas? >> Yeah. No, it's it's it's totally true and I think it's going to become even more true as coding just becomes easier and easier as these tools get better and better. You know, we see teams that are shipping products every single week, you know, running distribution on them for a month and a either just pivoting their product, maybe they, you know, had a great thesis, but the way, you know, users are actually leveraging and using their product is just different than, you know, they initially set out to. Um, and so, you know, just refining products so much quicker. I think that's just a way people have been testing, too. And then another way is just like, hey, like, do people actually care about this? Like, if I, you know, can run organic and get a few hundred users on this, like, will they stay? Will they continue to use the product? Will they turn out right away? Will any of them actually pay for this? And so, I think it's a really quick way to just like validate your idea, validate if like people care about it. Um, because like sure, you can get, you know, a couple hundred people to just download your product. Like that's one thing, but can you continue to get these people to, you know, stay on the product and, you know, even pay for your product? And so I think it's just been such a quick way to just really close that feedback loop. You know, you can hire a couple creators, pump out, you know, 30, 50 videos, you know, get a ton of eyeballs on it in a really short period of time and either make the necessary adjustments that you're seeing on the product. maybe switch the format, switch the messaging that you're using, maybe see if it's maybe better for a different target audience. And so I I just think there's a ton of experimentation. And I think the the beauty with UGC is like you can run so much experimentation for so cheap. You know, you're paying what is it 20 or so dollars for each video. Like you can run so many different formats. You can target a handful of different audiences if you're still trying to figure that aspect out. And like you can just iterate so much quicker and you know so much more cost-effectively. And that's why I think so many of these companies are now just like fundraising as app studios with the the like maybe some core thesis that they have and just testing that thesis out with, you know, 10 or 20 different products before they maybe find the two or three that they want to double down on. >> What deal structure would you do to get like minimum viable test? like would you book a creator for a whole month and get try to get 30 videos or would you do like one week of videos or would you do like one single video? How would you like approach that if you're just trying to test as quickly as possible? >> Yeah. So, I think if you're running paid um as opposed to organic, I think you could do creators on like a week-toeek basis. Maybe you have them pump out like five to 10 different formats that you just run paid ads across. Um, and I think you can get really good feedback there. Like, do any of these formats convert? Like, do people actually download when they see this? And like maybe we find one or two winning formats, maybe we double down on that. And, you know, then we can compare that to organic as well. And so I think for organic the challenge with a really short time period is, you know, you just don't get a ton of data. And I think it the game's a little bit different than paid. I mean, personally, I think like a two week timeline is pretty pretty sufficient. um you'll start to get a good sense of hey like especially if we have a few creators like if none of these creators accounts are moving and like even if their accounts are moving and getting views but we're not seeing conversions like why is that you know like try and figure out the why behind it and then like when you understand like maybe why things aren't working even if you pivot and you know run things over the next two weeks and are still seeing very similar you know results that just don't seem to be very promising then it's like one those things like, okay, maybe we need to question what we're building and what this thesis is. And, you know, maybe we just need to figure out, you know, a different product idea or a different, I guess, kind of take on whatever we're building right now. >> That's great. That's great advice. Super actionable. Is there anything else you wanted to I think that that was like the most of the stuff I wanted to cover. Is there anything else you wanted to cover? Yeah. I mean, I think one thing that I've been thinking a lot about in this kind of just consumer distribution space is how quickly it's evolved and changed. And I think, you know, we look back to, you know, 3 to four years ago was kind of just like when influencer marketing really started to take off. And I think like within the past, you know, couple of years, like it's kind of pivoted more into like this micro influencer marketing and like now it's kind of come down to UGC marketing. And so I think what's interesting is I think there will be a convergence in the sense that like, you know, the price that influencers are getting paid is coming down, you know, and the price that UGC creators it's kind of starting to converge. And I think the reality is is like these algorithms reward quality content and so you no longer need to have hundreds of thousands of followers to you know drive an impact and I think the reality is too like with cheaper creators there's so much more experimentation that can be done. I think the beauty of it too is like when you bring these creators on board, you know, it's going directly into your audience as opposed to, you know, an influencer. Like sure, they may be in your niche, but there's never a onetoone overlap. And so, I think it'll be interesting to see how this space continues to evolve. Um, yeah, I I think my my take on it is like the cost of, you know, influencer and micro influencer marketing will continue to drop down. I do think that massive enterprise brands will continue to dump money into it because the way I view it is more of just like brand awareness and tying your brand to a personality. Um, I don't necessarily think there's a strong ROI there. And that's why I think so many startups and even like middle to late stage growth companies are starting to lean into this kind of UGC playbook because they realize that like the ROI, the impressions that they're able to generate is just vastly, you know, cheaper than what you might have to pay to an influencer. And so I think the one thing that'll be interesting to see too is like as AI and the content that you can produce with AI evolves, it's like where does that pillar fit into kind of this scene? You know, I I think there's very much so a chance that it kind of can be just another distribution channel. I I see I think we're starting to see different use cases pop up there with especially with kind of V3 and you know the type of content that is starting to get produced out of there. I I I still think there's a definitely a level of skill that is, you know, being taken to have to produce that highquality content. Um, and so I think as those tools become more intuitive and, you know, they have more reach and kind of anyone can start to create this content, um, that will be really interesting to see and seeing even how creators can begin to leverage these tools and kind of use that as even a complement to, you know, the content that they're already making. >> It it reminds me of just like people people say marketing channels are dead. Like I I see these tweets all the time where people are like paid ads is dead, cold email is dead, you know, all like SEO is dead, but I feel like nobody's paying attention to organic UGC. It's just like such a sleeper channel. Like maybe it is it because it's Gen Z like why you think Sideshift is doing so well right now? like clear clearly like the results are good, but why why was no one else really doing this before you guys showed up? >> Yeah, I I think it I think there's a there's a few a few reasons. I think like number one is like this organic UGC stuff is still relatively new. Like I think you know like the hardcore consumer founders have been running this playbook for a while and I think you know these marketing channels they take time to start to reach you know bigger companies and other companies that just are not as familiar with the distribution space in general. And so I think as I think it'll continue to get more popular over time, like as people continue to have, you know, these insane results, it it's very similar with how influencer marketing and micro influencer marketing, you know, started to blow up for a few years um because people were having insane results. You know, app goes to number one running this playbook. It's the same idea. as more and more kind of proof of concepts start to evolve, more people will start, you know, being like, "Okay, I guess this actually is a viable marketing channel, I still think there's a lot of people that, you know, don't necessarily have a ton of faith in it." And I think sometimes, you know, those are just, you know, the late adopters and the people that kind of get to the punch first are going to continue to be rewarded. And I think, you know, as it gets a little bit more crowded, it'll be interesting to see like what strategies need to be taken to, you know, ensure that you're still getting, you know, good ROI from kind of that distribution lens. Um, I think another thing in terms of like why we've had a lot of success, I think there's something to be said about like our core demographic being college students. I think, you know, there's tons of creator marketplaces out there, but there's still really like influencer marketing in the sense that like it's content creators that already have massive followings on Tik Tok or Instagram that are going to these marketplaces to try and sign brand deals. And so when people come there to try and hire for UGC, there's just a little bit of a disconnect. And so I think like us going the college route from the start like I mean we physically went to 25 different college campuses in person to onboard kind of that first 10 to 20,000 users. And I think because of that like we've gotten really strong word of mouth and growth within college. Like I think a lot of people that see our content like it kind of just feels like this like college gen Z marketplace. And I think because we built up our core audience kind of in that space, we've actually been able to, you know, have a lot stronger results with the brands that we work with because the big thing is like these kids, you know, they're hungry. They're they're not able to find these jobs. Like they're not these massive influencers on TikTok that just have extremely high expectations. And a lot of them are just really eager to get experience. You know, working with a really fast growing startup that's building a really cool product is extremely exciting and being able to have a direct impact on their growth. Like that's more meaningful a lot of the time than you know the potential, you know, few hundred or few thousand dollars that you're going to get paid out. And so I think like we've just tried to instill with a lot of the businesses that we work with. It's like look like make this relationship more than just a transaction. Like try and you know build this as a relationship. Like we always frame it to our creators. It's like look you might start as a content creator but like next thing you know you could be a strategist for our campaigns or for some of the campaigns for the companies we work with. And like a lot of the times that leads to you know these growth marketing distribution roles which are starting to become more and more important. And so I think it's just more so a framing thing and just the reality that like hey these are college educated kids. They're smart, but they're hungry. And like when you pair those things together, I think you can really see some, you know, really impactful results. >> That's so true. I feel like um yeah, there's no like UGC school. There's no like University of UGC. So, the only way to really get these people into senior roles is to get them the experience first and then, you know, have them uh take on these head of growth roles. I've seen that so many times like start out as a Tik Tok intern and then they get good at it and then they can now manage and hire um and you know help grow you know more employees like uh more Tik Tok people um and you can like that's when you really scale.
