## [19/28] Meet The Guy Who Solved App Growth on TikTok
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_aNVPMvd8WU
Duration: 39:09
Words: 8,704

In the last year, the founders on Nick Weber's platform generated over 2.5 billion with a B views. >> 2.5 billion views seems like a crazy number. We were super surprised by the number, too. >> But even though they were surprised, this had nothing to do with luck. They're actually one of the few teams I've seen truly get viral Tik Tok growth down to a science. And it started with this weird discovery he calls the eggs theory. We noticed that the ones that were doing higher views always had some form of eggs on them. It's relatable. It's healthy. It's easily understood. it seems achievable because it's cheap. >> He realized that tiny, seemingly random details could be the difference between a thousand views and 10 million. So, he built a system to test all these details at a massive scale. Instead of hiring a few creators, he built a platform that allows 50,000 people to post content all at the same time. A lot of the other folks out there are taking, you know, five people, 10 people, and saying, "Hey, post this kind of content for us twice a day." And what we're saying instead is, "Hey, 50,000 people post this content." and he calls it the shots on goal effect. And he uses it to run two distinct playbooks at the same time. First, higheffort UGC videos designed to go viral with a soft call to action. And second, thousands of simple slideshows with a hard call to action that act as a retargeting campaign for anyone who saw the first viral video. Maybe the million view video is like a little bit of a softer CTA that like barely mentioned Noise app. And then all the like small view videos are a little bit harder CTA, which is probably why they didn't get as many views, but it's functioning sort of like as a retargeting ad. He doesn't guess what works. He just lets the data tell him. They found that a video starting with don't get a second job went viral, while the same video starting with everybody needs a side hustle flopped. You would be shocked at what is the thing that sets it off, right? Originally, we weren't using the don't get a second job as the start to this whole like paragraph text here. I think it was like everybody needs a side hustle. Don't get a second job is what ended up making it go viral. >> And what he's learning is that going viral has a lot less to do with being creative and much more to do with thinking like a scientist. You don't have to be super creative. You just have to be creative in showing how your app fits [music] or product or whatever it is fits into an existing viral format. I like to say I think Pablo Picasso is the one that said that great artists steal. In this episode, Nick Weber breaks down the science of virality. How to find winning formats by copying what already works. How to use a two-pronged content strategy to drive both awareness and conversion. And how to build a distribution machine that gives you an unfair advantage over everyone else. This is a master class in growth not as an art, but as a science. Let's get into it. This is the Superall podcast and I'm Joseph Choy, founder of Consumer Club. The members in the Consumer Club Discord and the founders I interview on the pod build apps at a median of about a million dollars ARR. In my conversations with dozens of these founders every week, one thing I've noticed is most of them AB test their payw walls to increase their conversion rates and make more money. Now, most people know that one of the best ways to AB test payw walls is Superwwell. But one thing you might not know is Superwwell has a lot of data on the thousands of apps that use their payw walls. So recently they actually put together a tool that takes 422 profitable paywall experiments and put those into a paywall experiment generator where you can upload a screenshot of your own payw wall and it'll give you an experiment idea to increase your revenue. You can use it for free at paywallexperiments.com. All right, let's get into the pod. Okay, so 1 year into noise and the founders on your platform have gotten more than two billion views which is pretty insane. first of all, how this was achieved, how those 2.5 billion views happened, and then also like how you guys got started. >> I mean, 2.5 billion views seems like a crazy number. [laughter] We were actually not really keeping track. We looked at it here at the end of the year to kind of like milestone what we've done in the last year. And we were super surprised by the number, too. We knew it was high, but we didn't know it was this high. It's just the accumulation of a bunch of stuff, right? Tons of super viral videos. We've got another one going out right now that's 22 million views in 4 days. It's those kinds of big ones and then what we call just like this massive ground game of hundreds of thousands of posts going out there that do 500 to a,000 2,000 views a pop and it really just starts to add up. >> So there's a bunch of like videos on your platform that are getting a bunch of views. What's the secret? How are they getting so many views? >> It's a distribution problem, right? And so a lot of the other folks out there are taking, you know, five people, 10 people and saying, "Hey, post this kind of content for us twice a day." And what we're saying instead is, hey, 50,000 people post this content and here's exactly what you need to post and here's all the assets for it and here's what you say and here's your description and it just goes absolutely crazy from there. We call it sort of like a shots on goal effect where just by naturally having a 100,000 pieces of content out there a day at least, you're going to get something that hits. And if it doesn't hit, it's going to quickly tell you why through, you know, analytics or just general viewership. And you can use that information to slightly tweak stuff to then make it just go crazy. [music] And I want to underscore how crazy it is that just changing the text or changing the picture or the first couple seconds of your video can be the difference between 1,000 views and 10 million views. Like it really just boils down as stuff that's that simple. >> Yeah. I want to get into kind of the science of that and all the little >> I'll talk to you about uh eggs theory. It'll blow your mind. >> Oh, just tell me that right now. In the early days when we were doing slideshows for a brand that we were working with, we noticed that the ones that were doing higher views always had some form of eggs on them. I can actually pull up an example here for you too. Yeah. So, this is just from one account and there were many of them doing this and you'll notice on all of these that aesthetically they're sort of similar, but they all have some version of egg in them. And so we started calling it the eggs theory and it really helped us solidify what hooks meant because we thought that the eggs here were making it go viral because it was about clean eating. It was about healthy eating. And eggs [music] are one instantly visually understandable. Not only are they a whole food and healthy, but they're also super affordable, right? Everybody knows what an egg is. The last election was based on the prices of egg cost, which is crazy that this little piece of food makes that much of a difference. You see over and over and over again that putting hard-boiled eggs, putting scrambled eggs in these first hook images just absolutely was a rocket ship in terms of viewership. >> I don't really get it, but like if it works, it works. Tik Tok is very mysterious. Sometimes >> it's all just about relevancy and then how it relates to the person that's watching it, right? You know, if you've ever tried to eat healthy before, you're probably eating scrambled eggs. You're probably eating hard-boiled eggs. This is aesthetically what you would call like, you know, Pinterest sort of design style. They're all AI generated and they just sort of hit whatever that nerve is for people that are trying to eat healthy. And that visual language and that visual relatability just instantly send them to the next slide. And that's huge signals to Tik Tok to push it into like, you know, crazy viral view ranges. So, I also want to give a disclaimer. Like, the reason why I invited you on the pod was because I had someone else on the pod, Kyle, and he just randomly brought up noise and he was just like, "This is basically how we do our mass slideshows." And he just promoted you guys for like 10 minutes straight. Yeah. I normally don't cover like platforms. I like to talk to founders mostly on Super Bowl channel, but I feel like you have a ton of insight. So, I'm excited to get into the all the Tik Toks. >> I mean, shout out Kyle. We're not here to charge somebody $15, $20,000 ahead of time to go make content for you. We're just building the tool and we want the tool for founders to access in a way that people have been able to access, you know, meta [music] ads, but meta ads just they don't work the way that people think that they should work and they're super expensive. So, we're just building the alternative to that, an absolute perfect case study of it. They're getting crazy views, good installs, and you know, we love to see that. >> So, you're trying to replace meta ads or be an alternative to meta ads. How does that actually work? >> I mean, we come from a background of, you know, performance marketing. That's where myself and the other founders really cut our teeth. And when we really started, we've been app founders for a long time. And when we first started, it was always, all right, well, yeah, performance marketing, that's the way to go get people. We did a bunch of really crazy growth hacks in the early days, too, that worked. But scale was a little bit different for those. I could tell some crazy stories about how we scaled up really really cheap traffic on our last app, but some of those are are definitely gatekept secrets that we want to hold close to the pocket, but really what we found out was that Tik Tok [music] was the best distribution system at cost. And when you see how Tik Tok works to serve people content and how Meta or even YouTube or Google or whoever else you want to compare it to works to serve content to people who are interested in, you know, whatever ad they're showing, the short form media content works exactly the same way, right? If you're interested in cats, you're going to get cat content on your short form feed. All you have to do is make your product relevant to that cat content and then boom, there you go. feels like completely organic discovery even if it's super super implicit and it just converts like absolute gang busters. So for us the aha moment was we started trying this for ourselves in July of 2024 and we just started handing some of our internal players slideshows that pseudo promoted our app at the time and when we had one slideshow do 20,000 views in a week. maybe this is the secret sauce and we just started asking other folks that we knew that were in the same space like building apps if they wanted to try it as well and it just kind of took off from there. This is our Discord chat right now. I'm very excited to get into all these cuz you just sent me all of these like Tik Toks that got tons of views and then also were like actually promoting a brand, but I feel like you have a ton of insight. So, I'm excited to get into the all the Tik Toks. So on the noise platform, the way that you have the all these slideshows go out is you basically upload a bunch of your own content, like the slideshows onto the platform and then hundreds of people come in and post those slideshows on their actual phones. Like the content is going out organically, but the creators on the platform aren't really creating the content themselves. So we have two different variations where we have people that just post, you know, shotgun slideshows where you're aiming for just total mass distribution. And then we also have a higher class of user who we've, you know, upskilled or graduated through our app into posting that kind of traditional UGC content that you're used to. And what we found is both running together at the same time works great. And the secret for us has always been don't make your creators think about how to create this content. Right? If you go into the noise app right now, we just give you everything. So all you need to do is worry about curating your account and posting that content on a regular schedule and then you're instantly getting feedback of I'm getting paid for every single view that I get. Creators on noise are not meant to really invent their own formats. You should just come with the format and then create the content and then they'll post it hundreds of times for you. And you pay CPM, right? So you don't pay creators like retainers or anything like that. You just pay like per how many views that they get. >> That's right. Yeah. And importantly on those CPMs too, you set them. So the brands that come in, we say, "All right, generally what are you trying to target for a download? What's your cost per install?" And that's usually what we set the CPMs at. So depending on their product, depending on how many views you get, there's a lot of different levers that you can pull, but just I mean for ourselves, we're averaging like 30 cent installs using our own platform. So the cost is just you can't compare it to anything else. It's insane when you get the machine up and running. >> Okay, so now we have the mechanisms. Can you just walk through some of these examples of successful Tik Toks that have been posted on the platform? >> Yeah, I mean just uh opening these Lingo Pingo examples. This is probably what people are most familiar with. This is the result of us basically handing our creators the idea that we think goes viral. An example for them to kind of look at of one that was similar. I think that the originator of this trend was some random woman who just made something she thought was funny of her like crying to pronounce some word on Google. When you're on Google Translate on the search engine results page, it tells you, you know, how to say this word correctly and she's just fumbling over it and crying, right? And then this concept can be applied to any language. And so these examples were shown to the creators. We give them the exact instructions on what to do, how to prompt the app, why it specifically works, why it's funny, using, you know, an innuendo, and having the app roast you. And we went to sleep and woke up the next day, and this already had like 20 million views on it. This format just absolutely ripped all through October and November of people crying to the app, the app roasting them, or 15 different variations of it. The concept of AI being mean to you, I feel like that is very applicable across different niches, too. And then if your app is about AI itself, maybe it's like a GBT rapper in some vertical, like the video will be about the app itself. So you're probably going to get these comments that say, "What's the app?" And then that's like very high converting. I'm sure everyone is familiar with the whole Craigslist analogy of every different form on Craigslist ended up being some unicorn company. What's interesting is there's a lot of similarities to popular subreddits in the content space as well. If you've been making content, this has been this way for years and years and years, but roast me is a super popular subreddit. And this is just roast me content from an AI, right? You can do sort of the same thing if you go through Reddit of really popular subreddits and say, "Oh, roast me is here. How can I make content that resonates with that crowd?" Because it's already been confirmed popular based on how people are interacting with the Reddit. That's a good like place to find the source of ideas, Reddit. Do you do that right now like to find new content formats? >> If I'm not familiar with the space, I will definitely look at Reddit just to understand how people talk about it. There is for sure nuance in how you talk about things, right? If you play a certain popular video game, the way you talk about that video game, it's pretty instantly clear if you know what you're talking about or if you don't. And these sort of online communities behave similarly. So Reddit is definitely a place where we take some inspiration, but ultimately the best inspiration is on whatever social media app you're posting on. I like to say we don't have to be super creative. We just have to have a good eye for what's already gone viral and how we can apply it to ourselves. And that's how we've hit number five in our category, number seven in our category twice in a row. Every time we've tried to hit top 10, we've done it by just copying what's already done well and slotting noise into those scenarios. >> Yeah, it's kind of meta. I'm curious to see how you actually do it with the Noise app. Let's look at a couple of these examples. Don't get a second job. Instead, download the Noise app. I make noise posts every night for $20. It doesn't sound like a lot, but it adds up. It's additional $500 a month, which helps with groceries. Why did this go viral? >> There was a woman who had posted this very similarly, and it was talking about her cleaning up Airbnbs after church, and that's how her and her husband like make some extra spending cash, right? So, I'm like, okay, clearly this resonated. So now I just have to take that similar concept and we put it into playbooks and noise give it to our noise users and they post it. And this one since we use our own platform this was doing 8 cent installs for about 3 days and this hit us to number seven in our category. Really the conversion is what is the noise app? I haven't heard of this thing before. How does it work? And you can see people in the comments here like asking what is the noise app? How does it work? To be clear this was not the only one. We had like four, five, six, one of a similar post that all did over a million views and uh it was always washing the dishes. We tried vacuuming. We tried pouring coffee into a cup, but none of it worked the same way that washing the dishes did. >> So there's like a bunch of different people like all doing the same thing, but in each of their houses, just like washing dishes with basically the same caption on top, or was it like variations of the caption, too? >> Subtle variations. Like I had mentioned, you would be shocked at what is the thing that sets it off, right? Originally, we weren't using the don't get a second job as the start to this whole like paragraph text here. Don't get a second job is what ended up making it go viral. And so, if you start breaking those down, no one really likes being told what to do. Saying you need a side hustle is making a bunch of assumptions that the viewer might be uncomfortable with or whatever else, right? There's like a lot of nuanced psychology there. However, don't get a second job is still saying the same thing, but it is provides like a totally different like sentiment to the same concept. And little changes like that are again that difference between 10,000 views and a million views. >> There's like some kind of novelty effect of this too where it's like you can really make $20 a day by making posts like with an app. It just seems like almost not too good to be true, but it's like crazy concept. People probably immediately go to the comments and looking for like people that are calling it out as a scam or something. But you just you kind of like organically have people like saying like, "Hey, I actually have it. Like it worked." And then some people like asking genuinely, oh, how do you actually do this? So, it seems like people were by default not that skeptical. I think people were just like, oh, how do you do it? Like, how does this actually work? >> We've tried, I've made $7,000 and whatever. And the crazy thing is like we have users that have made $7,000 in a week on our platform. But as soon as they say that, everyone's like, "Oh, no. This is a scam. I don't believe it at all." So, that's where it's like we take $20 seems super achievable, right? Anyone can imagine a $20 bill in their hand, but then they're bad at math. So you say, "Oh, it's actually an extra $500 a month." And then that $500 is what they anchor on of, "Oh, my car payment is like $498 a month." Like that would be my car payment. That would be incredible. >> There's a little bit of a a like get-richqu guru inflation going on where there's like all these wild claims like 10,000 a month. I mean, I'm guilty of on this channel, too. I cover people who actually make that much money, but like people in the are always in the comments being like, "Oh, that's inconceivable. How could you actually make that much money?" But then like when you say, "Oh, this guy's making an extra 15k a month." And it's like, "Oh, actually like that's, you know, similar to my tech job." Like I could see myself making that. >> We figured this out way in the old days when we were doing our last app. It doesn't even matter if you show people receipts. Like if I show you my bank stub of how much I made posting on noise, everyone would be like, "Nope, that's fake. There's no way that's real." And so for us, it was a lot of just recentering people. So, is this how you actually prompt your creators and you just let the creators kind of like mix and match the slides and like change up the the text? >> This was an internal tool for us where we like to do things that don't scale and then when we prove that they work, we scale them up. Our version of don't scale here was taking 30 of our most engaged users from our last app that were active in our community and saying, "Hey guys, we want to pay you to just post content on TikTok and we're going to give you all that content." And we had no other distribution method besides just handing them canvas slideshows. And so in the early days, like I would sit here and I make canvas slideshows myself. I know nothing about Brawl Stars. never played it before, but we knew there was massive demand capture in our player base at the time because we had a lot of people coming to the the app that we had at the time that played Brawl Stars. And so we knew that if we just made Brawl Stars content and at the end had a very explicit call to action here, Playbite's the fastest way to get gems if you know, you know, and have 35 people post it. We thought, you know, people will check it out and probably download Playbite. And we were just not prepared for how successful that would be. We went from just handing people canvas slideshows where they can edit things slightly or add their own pictures if they wanted to to having it all be served through the noise app and they don't even have to do this editing anymore. We just automatically do all the variations for them, give them to them in different orders, different texts, randomize all of it so it's all unique content that goes out. >> That's an interesting way of doing creative production that I think is like somewhat unique. This itself makes a good slideshow, but you can't have a 100 people post the same exact thing. you need to make variations in the text or the images and you're saying that the noise platform actually helps you do that. >> To be completely transparent, I've never posted on TikTok until July of 2024. This was just a a growth hack for us that turned into absolute obsession and necessity where it's now a game to figure out how do you make stuff go viral? How do you learn all of it? And we got to where we are by doing it ourselves. Really, all of this was learned through a lot of trial and error on our side, right? where we were trying to figure out what worked and what didn't and why and then build that into a product for ourselves to use that others could utilize. And this is our noise dashboard. So this is us running our own content through the platform. But importantly inside of the slideshows here we have this super basic one. You know I changed my life in 10 days. Slide 1 2 3 4 5. And we're setting exactly what all the captions are that come up. Everything that you see here you know this text that comes with the image. We've found that having the user actually paste that text on it inside of Tik Tok is better than just baking the text right on it. It sends a better signal to Tik Tok that it's, you know, a a real user doing the thing or could go into all sorts of my theories of how Tik Tok looks at information, whatever else. But all of these captions are set and then are randomized based on one all the images that you also set. So these would be the hook images. These would be the secondary option which is day one I found a girl on Tik Tok. So this is using that listical format that we talked about, right? And then the outcome is just a billion different variations of these slideshows that have different text, different hook images, different descriptions, different hashtags that all get sent to our users to then go post. What's really important here is I'm not looking for these to go viral, right? You can see there's 2 million views on them in the last 30 days as well, which is a small piece of that pie compared to everything else that's going out. But these serve as just total shotgun effect where if you've done programmatic marketing before, you're familiar with how Facebook does retargeting campaigns. We view these slideshows for us when we run both the the UGC side and the slideshow side. These function very similar to retargeting campaigns. And the cool thing is like if you have something viral for noise, you're going to see more noise content. And so we try and serve it up to people in a similar format and very explicit call to action here on what you can expect, right? Where I open this up and it's how I completely changed my life day one, day whatever. And there's just hundreds and hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of these going out that drive that bottom ofunnel action, especially once you've seen something that's very viral. So there's kind of like a power law distribution here where the top videos are getting millions of views and then all the rest of videos are getting like a few thousand views, but the videos that get a few thousand views are getting shown on the feeds of those same people who watch that like viral million view. Maybe the million view video is like a little bit of a softer CTA that like barely mentioned noise app and then all the small view videos are a little bit harder CTA which is probably why they didn't get as many views but it's functioning sort of like as a retargeting ad. We've only really noticed this because we unlocked the scale and distribution part. That's the hardest part to do is to just get everybody posting all the same thing that you want and subtle variations of it to find your winners. We could spend time to try and make a slideshow go viral, but that's just not how we are using it for ourselves. We're very much more hunting for the viral hits more like UGC side where we have big ones like this go out like 3.8 million views, 5 million views, 2 million, 2 million, 1.6. Like these are the ones that are driving a lot of that discussion, a lot of that commenting, a lot of that curiosity that then those slideshows just come in with their explicit call to actions to then drive the user to actually go download noise. >> So you put in like a bunch of effort into UGC like UGC inherently is like a lot more effort. you need the human to like act like with their face and it's a little bit more manual versus the slideshows like you don't put as much effort in. You like put tons of combinations in just to like flood the feed. So, it's kind of like a two-pronged approach. You have the the UGC which is high effort. I want to go into like hot takes. So you have a lot of interesting hot takes and I want to just like get you to explain some of these. Hot take number one. Videos with less than 500 views still convert. Why do you believe this? >> The Tik Tok algorithm is incredible. That's really what unlocks all of this is they understand when you post something who should see it and why they should see it and why it's relevant to them, right? It all goes back to relatability and relevance. Tik Tok is doing its absolute best every single video, every single view to show that to the right audience. If you have something like, let's just say a noise slideshow for example, and it gets seen by 500 people, Tik Tok is doing its best to send it to the right 500 people as fast as it possibly can. And it's pretty good at it. And so we see over and over again that if you post a thousand videos and they get a,000 views a pop and you're doing a million views on it, you will get downloads. You might not see the kind of like viral explosive I'm now number one in my category from massive amounts of content that are getting 500 views a pop, but it absolutely still does convert. And we've got plenty of math to prove that's true. >> Okay, so you have another theory. Tik Tok has a daily views budget. What does that mean? Let's just say the growth hack space inside of Tik Tok, right? If you're making growth hack content on Tik Tok for other founders to watch, Tik Tok knows that generally this many founders that are interested in this content are going to be on Tik Tok today. They're only going to watch X amount of content. It's not like Tik Tok can't really take 50 million more videos and just plop it into the platform because they can't just suddenly generate the interest or the swipes to accumulate for all those 50 million views in the same way. Right? Right? So that's when people say like, "Oh, the algorithm hates me because my content isn't being shown to anybody." Part of that might just be your content is not good enough to be shown to anybody, right? And Tik Tok is pitting you against other content that's out there in similar formats. But if you're making content in the growth hack space for founders, if [music] you just add 5,000 extra videos in that space a day, they're just going to take that budgeted amount of general views they think that that content gets each day and just spread it out more. And we've seen this like over and over and over again where if you make let's just say content in the book space, [music] you post viral book slideshows like this one and these are getting a million views a pop, 2 million views a pop on some of the other accounts and then you have 10,000 people run it and post the same similar kind of content. You're not going to see those big pops anymore. You're going to see them more spread out because Tik [music] Tok can't allocate the same viral views to all of that content because they just can't generate more people's interest during the day. So they're like budgeting out how [music] people are actually interacting with that content based on how good it is. >> Do you feel like it's because of competition? When you think of an individual users perspective, they don't want to watch a thousand videos in a row about the same exact thing. >> If you open your Tik Tok or Instagram right now, you'll swipe past 50 million John Ham Dancing in the Club memes. That that happens regardless, right? All these platforms are absolutely starved for content. It definitely gets shown multiple times and you know if I was designing the Tik Tok algorithm I wouldn't want to show you the same thing over and over and over again. That variability is what makes it so addicting just by nature of pumping these platforms full of similar content. You will get surfaced in the same way and Tik Tok understands that it's similar to what's already out there. So either reserve or they give new ones a shot and then recognize that they're similar and then those peter out until they get a new one in there. They give that one a shot and etc etc etc. I might not mind if I see like a hundred John Ham memes in a row today. Maybe my my personal budget for that many memes is maybe 50 tomorrow and then maybe the next day it's like 10 and then after that I probably don't want to see it ever again. Maybe once every week. I think that what I just described is like the concept of a trend. It's like Tik Tok is allocating probably like a pretty huge TAM for certain trends. If it's an engaging format like people will watch it over and over again, but then eventually like kind of gets old and then you find something new. But within that trend, it doesn't really matter if you get a,000 videos that get 1,000 views each or one video that gets a million views each. You're still getting shown to people because the size of that like the TAM of that trend is a certain amount 100%. And that's again why we're on this hottake of like 500 views on a video for sure converts. I could pull up screenshots of people asking what app is that on videos with 200 views because Tik Tok is incentivized to try and show you the most relevant content as fast as possible. >> That makes sense. Yeah, I think Kyle showed a couple of those examples as well from his Canamon stuff. You said something really important that I want to hit on. You said the word trends and that's what's so cool about this space is you can talk about the same thing just in different ways and ride those trends. And it's a neverending supply of fresh ideas and new ways to talk about your stuff. I don't know if you saw this, but Dualingo had an article out there where they said that their numbers were falling because they weren't doing unhinged content. anymore. If you remember like the Dualingo owl died and you know did all this crazy and their unhinged content was just riding or creating their own trends. Everybody knows Dualingo, but if you get shown Duolingo again in a format that is trending or familiar to you or whatever else, it's another impression that Dualingo has to convert you or bring you back to their app. just like they do their viral marketing, we're just riding those exact same waves and giving you the ability to like [music] see how it's working way faster. >> Final hot take which I think will be relevant to anyone watching is you say that anyone can learn to go viral. >> Absolutely anybody. If you sat next to the kid in art class and you know his painting looks incredible and yours like looks like crap, that's just because he had some sort of inherent ability to see color or shape different or is more familiar with using a paintbrush or whatever else. But if I sit down and I grind to become a better painter, I will either get as good as him or surpass him. Right? Natural talent can only take you so far. If you're interested in learning how to do it, absolutely anybody can do it. And we have like proof through myself, our other team members. Like I'd never gone viral before. I'd never even posted in short form content before. And I've done it over and over and over again. We've shown all of our creators how to do it. And it's never a surprise to me when somebody who comes to the platform is like, "Oh, I posted and I've never had more views than this in my life. Thanks. This is incredible." >> I think I agree. It makes a lot of sense to me. This was really this is a very unique interview. Um, I learned we like we learned so much about like specific formats and the tactics. ## [20/28] I Built a $30k/mo App That Helps You Quit Smoking
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cYcU4_HQdIk
Duration: 32:14
Words: 8,576

It's hard to blow up on organic a lot. We know people who've gotten 10 million views on videos and made a thousand bucks. But if you can give this onboarding the intention and care it deserves, then everything else in your business becomes very easy. This is probably like from a consumer perspective the dumbest thing I've ever seen. But when we put this in, we've seen our reviews like skyrocket on our app store page, going from 50 reviews to almost at a thousand right now. And it's just continuing to grow as more people come through the app. We changed the payw wall once and we went from 20% conversion to 30% conversion. We went from doing 10k in subscriptions last month and then we made 30k in subscriptions this month and the trajectory keeps going up like that. What if I told you there were two founders who found a way to triple their app revenue in 8 weeks. Meet Asher and Thatcher. 2 months ago, their addiction recovery app, Clear 30, was pulling in a modest 10K a month. Fast forward to today and they've blown past 30K a month and they're still climbing. But they didn't just get lucky to see this kind of success. They systematically tested everything. I'm talking everything from ad creatives that bombed versus ones that converted at three times the rate to onboarding flows that confused users versus ones that led straight to paid subscriptions all the way to payw wall copy that felt pushy versus messaging that actually convinced people to invest in their recovery. They documented every experiment, tracked every metric, and figured out exactly what psychological triggers turn a curious user into a paying customer in the addiction recovery space. So today we're pulling back the curtain on their entire playbook. The real numbers, the failed tests, and the three breakthrough discoveries that changed everything for them. If you've got a consumer app that's stuck in revenue limbo, the next 45 minutes might just be your road map out. Let's dive in. And if you aren't familiar with the pod, this interview is brought to you by Superwall, the all-in-one platform for paywall management and revenue analytics for your mobile apps. Asha and Thatcher and Clear 30. They use Superwall. We go straight into their dashboards in the video. Let's get right into it. Introduce yourself and what app are you working on. What's up? I'm Asher Hurstman, a co-founder of Clear 30. >> I'm Thatcher Kloff, also co-founder of Clear 30. >> Together with our other amazing, brilliant co-founder, Dr. Fred Munch, who's a clinical psychologist. We've built Clear 30, which is a science-based app. Helps give people a system to stop smoking weed if they're brutally addicted or just want to take a little break and start smoking with intention and moderate. The app can help them whatever they want. Yeah, we haven't done like millions of revenue. We started out as actually complete idiots in this app world. You're like guiding them through pain agitated solution and there's a lot of copy. There's a lot of like visuals. It almost feels like your ads are just bringing people in the door and not really talking too much about the pain points or the solution or any of the product or anything. And then you kind of mainly talk to the user through the onboarding instead of the content in the ad. Is that how you think about it? >> It can be both as well. But like no matter what your onboarding should be the best conversation. You should be able to engage them in your onboarding. It should be more than just getting set up and then hey give me money like through a Tik Tok ad or anything. You don't have the opportunity to engage them deeply. They're not in there. So once you get them there, you have to do everything you can to give them an incredible experience and then make them want to make this change in their life. A great thing you can do with ads is, and like I know a lot of people are already doing this, but you know, see what your competitors in your field or market or niche are posting and see what's working for them. We have this one competitor called a reframe, which is like an alcohol quitting app. It's not the same niche, but it's the same similar thing in the industry. They were running something that was like, take our quiz to see what alcohol type you are. You don't always have to say, "Hey, get this app. Change your life. Do all this." Cuz people might not be ready for that. But if you say, "Hey, just take the quiz. See your relationship percent with weed." And then use that as your opportunity to sell them can be really huge. >> And I will say that it wasn't super helpful because the intent of people coming in. I think we our onboarding was not as good at the time. Does framing the onboarding as a quiz get more people to convert? While it didn't work for us, it totally could for a different product or like a different introduction or if it's just done better because to be honest, we didn't put our all into it. We didn't have our focus on like, okay, let's focus on getting more people in and converting all of them. If that became a focus, then I'm sure that we would put in enough work for this to work. This is super helpful. I love how deep into all the sales training and marketing frameworks you guys go. There's a reason behind every single like micro decision that it seems like you guys are making. I'm kind of curious to see if you have the same mindset around ads, too. In terms of ad creatives, it's a similar thing where we look at the creatives that are working and like the ones that you know Meta or Tik Tok are allocating the most spend to maybe the ones with like super high click-through ratings or just trying to like look at all like the primary secondary metrics and just try to understand why they're doing well. And through those ads, we can kind of take like hypothesises. Oh, we did this ad. This ad had a girl in it and it did like way better than the one that with a guy in it. This ad looked like it was filmed on a camera and it did so much better than the one that looked like it was filmed on a great one. And I think it's been a bit less organized in terms of like I don't have a spreadsheet of saying like this hook is great, this hook is not good. It's more intuitive of like looking at the hooks that are doing well and then just working those in and then seeing if those are doing well and then going back and forth. And that's something I think we could work on is having like a big company document of like hypothesises. And I would like suggest for other app like app founders, but understanding why they make every single decision. For me, I think about it all the time as I'm waking up, going to bed of like why stuff's hitting, why is not. But like I could definitely do a better job of like making that public within the company and having like, you know, creating a very strong system about like this hook did this, this hook did that. Some of the reason that we don't have as many small tweaks is that a lot of our ads are very thought out and scripted and filmed. And so it's not as easy to say, let's change this one word or change this one sentence in it and then refilm the whole thing because that's kind of just not the format of the ads that we work on and we see doing the best. But like Asha said, we do take those parts that work like, oh, this is a good hook. Oh, focusing on the trigger of friends around you smoking in some specific situation is really helpful. So I think that the formats are somewhat different. I feel like a lot of people think about, okay, how do I get profitable ads? they just make better and better ads, but you guys are just you're optimizing every part of the funnel. >> Like it's hard to blow up on organic a lot and it can be a lot of effort and it can be, you know, not always converting. And we know people who've gotten 10 million views on videos and made a,000 bucks off of 10 million views. And it's just like there can be so much uphill battle, but if you can give this onboarding the intention and care it deserves and really think about that all the way through, then everything else in your business becomes very easy. And this is like another framework that we've used and like we struggle to focus a lot where like you know when you're building an app there's a million things that are being thrown at you. There's this and this customer and you have a million ideas to improve the app and they're all great and they would all work if you did all of them but you can really only do like one thing. So just stripping away and thinking you know if this one thing would change in my business and would be perfect like it would solve all other problems and then just doubling down on it till it hurts till it's like why are we doing this? Like you know we were focusing on onboarding and ads for 2 months straight. I feel like one thing to like sort of close this out is you guys are just really fun to watch. You guys are like fun to talk to. I feel people are going to be speculating on what your future plans at. What are the future plans now? >> Right now we kind of cracked paid ads. We're scaling it. And so we're trying to keep focusing on what's working well, which is making these big incremental changes, but there are also a lot of big 10x or 100x changes we can make. We have a big partnership pending with like the University of Michigan to push it out to their faculty as well. But I think that there's a lot to be done with the B2B side of this. There are actually a lot of people really struggling with weed in this country and I think like going to some of these organizations like addiction services, state services where people are struggling and giving them this app can really benefit them. You know, a lot of our users are asking for supplements. A lot of our users are asking for therapy. So, thinking about ways to, you know, change up our money models and giving them upsells and downells and reorganizing basically our the way we're making money in a way that can really increase the LTV of our users is something we're also very focused on. Who knows? just take all of our skills somewhere else and and build something else great. >> I love that. ## [21/28] How I Built the #1 App on The App Store (Twice)
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jZ1W85VdIBk
Duration: 42:12
Words: 8,313

Roger Chen built two viral consumer social apps. And the crazy thing is both hit number one on the app store. The first one, Lobby, reached 500,000 daily active users and hit number one in the app store in five different countries. No paid marketing, just pure productled viral growth. The second one, Bro, is an AI companion that lives on your lock screen and floats over your text. It hit number one on the US app store off the back of Tik Tok, but Roger didn't even finish building the app before he started testing it. So this one is made by my co-founder Leo. It's like a mockup, but it's not the real apps like PowerPoint. Like we use this product called Protoy and then he just films everything like it's just like a fake mockup and then see if people like it. The central problem Roger's been thinking about for years is how do you make online conversations feel like IRL hangouts? Because right now every video call feels like a conference room and every group chat eventually dies. So with lobby, he literally rebuilt the college dorm lobby experience. spontaneous, low pressure with background activities like YouTube and SoundCloud, so you're never just staring at each other in awkward silence. The app idea was great, but consumer social is notoriously hard. Everything changed when they made this one single breakout feature. >> So the the feature we made is a >> that change was a turning point for them. And once that feature was implemented, people started inviting their friends to the app like crazy. And with Ro, Roger is taking it even further. He's embedding an AI companion directly into the apps you're already using, your texts, your dating apps, your camera roll, because the insight is basically AI companions should not live in a black box. They should live with you in the apps you already use. But he validated this idea before writing a single line of production code. All he did was buy Tik Tok ads, test formats, and found which user interface of the app resonated with people. Then he scaled the concept with 50 creators on Tik Tok. in the beginning like ads are really the fastest the fastest way to get feedback. There's this period of time between you first have the idea and when you first launch like that period could take 2 weeks a month even 2 3 months like that's the most dreadful period because you're just in your head you know you have no feedback and you can easily go on the wrong path. So, in this pod, Roger breaks down everything. The exact productled growth strategy that got lobbyed to 500,000 daily active users. Why he prototypes everything in his platform before he builds and his framework for using ads as validation instead of for scaling. Um yeah, so so like I see tremendous value in companions. Um so a lot of people a lot of people are like Don Kong companions for you know hey for for it being dystopian. Uh and the reason they think that is that a lot of the companions out there are trying to like displace your real world relationships. Uh it's like hey you don't need to talk to your friends but you know just talk to it instead. And uh I think like two things around that right. So first of all definitely like that's not what we want to do. So we want our product to augment your social relationships instead of like displacing them. Like having some kind of interactions with your friends is just inherently fun while talking incessantly to an AI black box is kind of depressing. Uh we can we can theorize on why that is but that's just the case. And um I think the second thing about companion is that you got to stop thinking of it as some kind of like real world friend entity and start thinking about it like some kind of like convenient uh in between. And what I mean by that is that I think whenever some new tech comes out uh people will dunk on it for not being as good as the real thing. it it's like Door Dash is never as good as a restaurant, but that's not the point. The point is that it's more accessible now. So, I think it's a little bit like that. So, we want to really make it more accessible, but at the same time, instead of like replacing social interaction, like really try to augment your social interaction. So, that's the thing we're obsessed with. One thing we've been grappling for a long time, and this actually like relates to back to my last company, lobby, is the idea that like when you actually hang out with like your friends in real life, uh you don't have a specific intent, right? You just want to hang out and you just want to say whatever and it's about the vibe. It's not about the topic. However, like I think in the online world, especially like when everything happens like asynchronously, it's almost like every time you reach out, there has to be an intent. And what we trying to do with everything we do here is like normal days bro or lobby is that we want to make it so that you can get together even when you have nothing specific to talk about and that really unlocks a whole lot more conversation. >> Yeah. What's the biggest learning that you got from lobby that you're taking into bro and like future startups? >> Yeah, maybe I can share a little bit more about like the the the context like things like behind lobby like why we why we started it. So yeah uh we started it uh after co and um I think like after co a lot of people are like video chatting uh talking to friends like catching up online and we always get this feeling that you know supposedly it should be like people hanging out online right just like chatting but it always feels less like a hangout and more like a conference call um and because it like think about it like you're in Zoom you're like staring at each other and it's like if there's a moment of silence then it becomes really awkward. Um it's almost like people are hanging out in a conference room. So that's the process of it and the and the trigger of starting that conversation is also pretty weird. It's like hey do you hey want to hop on a Zoom right now? Like people just don't do that right? Um, let's say if you want to hang out with a friend, uh, you never say, "Hey, let's go to a room and talk." It it's like the friend is the friend's going to think you're going to fire them or something. Uh, and um, yeah, it's always some you always find some kind of excuse like, hey, let's get some coffee, let's get some drinks, watch a movie. There's always some kind of uh, background activity. So, and the insight behind lobby is really that like people are going to hand out online, but it's got to be spontaneous and chill. Like by spontaneous, it means that nobody should ever feel like they are organizing a handout. Like there nobody should ever feel like they're initiating something like the inspiration really came from like our college days like which is um you know like you're going back to your dorm, right? And uh you're going upstairs and there's always this like big common area where people are like just sitting there like they're just lying there uh pretending to do homework but never doing homework and uh and there's always some like music or old movies playing. So that's a background activity and whenever you're free you just sit down there and people know you're free to talk. And that's why it's called lobby because literally like when I went to where I went to school at Chicago like uh like there's a huge lobby area like in my dorm building and people are just like sitting there all the time. So yeah so that's the idea behind lobby which is you know hey you know you should just be it should just be a place where you can drop in and chat and when you chat there should be some some kind of background activity. So for lobby it's like people are watching YouTube together, SoundCloud together, uh, and they're playing games together and screen share together. So if you think about it, there's actually a line from lobby to bro, which is you're doing stuff together instead of, you know, just like staring at you in the face and hey bro, let's find something to talk about. Yeah, >> right. That's totally true. I feel like college is just this magical spontaneous time that everyone wants to get back to if you went to college and they're just like there hasn't really been like a >> no there has not >> widescale solution to that. Yeah. >> Yeah man. You know especially now in SF man like every >> every place is very high intention. >> Yeah. >> Yeah. So then how how did this go? you got 500,000 users, daily active users on lobby and then what happened? >> So yeah, so what happened was we actually like struggled with it for a while. So in the beginning we did not get like meaningful like quality growth. So what that means is we would have people coming in and there will be like power users but overall like retention was not that good and uh and what and as a result we did not really grow for like a year. I think our big break came uh in 2022 like of all places like lobby just suddenly went viral in Israel uh of all places. Uh so yeah, nobody's going to market in Israel, right? It's like like 7 million people and but it suddenly like went viral and became number one on the app store and just stayed there and all the data is just like super super good. uh like I think like the day 90 uh for uh lobby in Israel back then was like 25 to 30%. Uh so like super solid and like the retention in other places like half that and when we looked at it like there's only really one key difference uh which is the network density because like in lobby we do have public rooms but it's majority like people talking with their friends uh and which is very intuitive because like nobody's like outgoing enough to talk to random people every day right but you always have some time to talk to your friends every day >> um in Israel um like the key difference between Israel and and the other market I think in like at the start of 2022 is that I think on the first day uh so we we tracked this like one number which is like the percentage of people who got five friends um day one uh in other places it's like like 20% but in Israel it's like 60%. So that's the difference and that led to like super high retention which leads to even more growth. So that was a huge inspiration, right? And um so we know that the answer is really really to double down whatever it takes um to get our density up. What that means is like this is not something that's solvable through content marketing and obviously if you do content marketing you're just going to be a whole lot more of you know like like random people without friends. Starting from that we started to really work on growth features. So it really has to be people inviting their friends through using the product. So we did like a whole lot of things to boost like inviting and sharing like we did the common things I can think of and then we also did some pretty wacky things. Um yeah like one thing I I still love to this day is a feature called like group picture. The idea is when you hang out in real life, let's say you are hanging out like in Dolores Park or something, you're just like sitting on the on the grass, right? And uh you have nothing to talk about with your friends and what will people start doing? They're going to start taking group pictures. So like when you have nothing to do, people are going to start taking pictures and uh and when you start whip out camera and people get excited again, people like, "Yay!" And then and then they're gonna you're going to have like something to talk about afterwards. So the the feature we made is a group picture when uh during the the video chat handout. So it's like you press the button and then everyone sees on their screen like three two one like a countdown and the phone vibrates and then you take a boomerang of a picture. Um and then people are going to share it to their like stories like Snapchat stories, Instagram stories and that does like two things like number one it um obviously gets a lot of more sharing out right and uh number two the friends who are not in a handout are going to be like how did this happen without me and then they're going to come the next time. So yeah, so we did a lot of wacky things to get the network density up. Uh and uh three months later lobby became number one in the UK and then Italy and then Germany. Oh yeah. And then and then starting from the UK I think like some people in the UK spread it to some some people in international schools in Cairo, Egypt. Apparently those people are like kind of like influencers in Egypt. So when they started using it like a lot of like young people in Egypt started using it too and my lobby became number one in Egypt and then Saudi too. So it's uh pretty magical. So lobby is really a tale of you know obviously you have to do seeding like I'm not saying like you don't need to do any content marketing because you do you do still need to like seed the users for them to invite their friends but after that to scale it really comes down to the product. Yeah, >> that's one of the most insane growth hacks, like productled viral growth um strategies I've heard about. That's really interesting. It's like you're combining the IRL experience with the invite flow. A lot of people do the classic stuff where it's like invite, you know, five friends and you unlock some sort of social benefit or um invite a friend and you get a discount or whatever it is. But this was literally just like it tells you to take a group picture with whoever you're with during your video chat and then it creates a a sharable piece of media which is the boomerang. You could share that on Instagram and then everyone else sees it. Was that watermarked? And then like people see the see the >> Oh, of course. 100%. Yeah, you bet. >> And then how did you get people to take the group picture while they were actually with people? If they're on a video chat, aren't they like sitting in their room like on their bed like you know doing these one minute video chats? >> I think we have a rule where you know every like five or 10 minutes like the button is going to light up you know it's it's going to hint that you can take the picture right now. And one key thing about like the group picture feature is that um it has to it has to be a shared experience. What I mean by that is that even right now I'm talking to you, right? I can like I can take a screenshot, right? But that's just creepy, you know, that that's not fun, you know? That's just like sniping you, you know? And and what we want is that everyone needs to know a picture is going to happen and then they get excited. So it's not about, you know, me, you know, taking a picture on my own. is about everyone be like it's happening and then let's take let's pose let's do some like crazy you know let's do do some crazy faces. So that's like a very key ingredient. It has to be a fun like group activity instead of like something instead of like a secret screenshot. Uh so so that's one. And number two is like we do have this um feature where when you exit a chat you're prompted to take a picture. It's like, "Hey guys, see you >> picture. Bye." And uh uh yeah. And and the third thing is like you mentioned the uh one minute uh video call, right? So that's actually like not the main feature. That's like a growth feature. Um so the main feature is really just like people staying there and then when you're free, you can drop in to chat with me. Uh and um that's the main feature. The one minute thing is more like it's more like a roll call. So we talk about density, right? Like one thing we struggle with is you know with a real-time product you don't you not only need like relationship density you'd also need like temporal density which is like density in time. You have to be online at the same second. If I miss you by one second the app is useless. The one minute call thing is really just a a little game like to that we added on top of that which is like you know at night um you know at a random minute you know the app is going to you're going to see like a little little bar pop up and then you can it's like hey talk to your friends for one minute like catch up for one minute right now and then you can join it and you can you see your friends and you go ah wah wah wah and then and then one minute is over the the chat just ends. The reason why we made it one minute is that we want to make it like super low pressure. It's like, Joseph, I want to see you, right? But um I I don't wanna >> I don't want to talk to you for like an hour. >> Yeah. I don't want to I don't wanna >> I don't want to Yeah. I don't want to be held hostage, you know? It's like >> Yeah. Uh what I mean by context is that um in lobby right you got a bunch of people chatting in the same room. If it's just me and you maybe the chat would have ended a long time ago but if there's a third guy then the third guy can be uh some kind of hype man or you know the third guy is going to say like really smart things or really stupid things but it's going to like keep opening up more topics uh and then both you and me are going to share more. So that's what happens when you have a concrete p concrete character uh that can like interact with like the real people. Right now there's a lot of talk around AI content uh which is great you know I I I love it like I first day I got my hands on Sora I made like maybe like 20 videos and um but but but in terms of our company we want to go the other direction which is instead of using AI to create content we want to use AI to create context because at the end of the day I feel like when you have so much AI flying around like authentic human interaction uh becomes even more valuable. This is a client that has been on our platform for less than four weeks and they've generated 4.7 million views just with 15 accounts. So this is V1 phone farm on devices so it looks like we're real creators so that we can run AI accounts on Tik Tok. It got 280,000 views. But that just validated that this could work. And as soon as it got three sales I went to the print shop and I gave them a deposit. I was like yours like 100 bucks as soon as I call just like print my posters. You want AI to do like 95% of the work and then human comes in 5% for touch-up. I don't think AI is there yet to do the the last 5% and nor do I sell that dream. >> Today we're sitting down with Zuhair Lani who's built what honestly might be the most sophisticated AI content operation I've ever seen and he's been crushing it. He generated over $100,000 in revenue in a single month using completely AI generated Tik Tok content. His agency hit 40K a month while he was still in college and now he's raised a million dollars from A16Z for his startup. But the thing that makes Zuher's story different is that he didn't start in tech. He actually got started in reselling and retail arbitrage during COVID. Brought supreme style hype tactics to restaurant marketing and eventually crack the code on making AI content at scale. What he's built with his new startup is unlike anything I've seen in the content space. He's built physical phone farms that can warm up hundreds of Tik Tok accounts. And he's also built AI that generates winning content formats with a feedback loop that makes the videos more viral over time. In this pod, Zuher breaks down his entire playbook from spotting arbitrage opportunities across industries to building systems that can run 25 brands simultaneously. He reveals exactly how he uses controversy and scarcity to create demand and why he believes the traditional creator economy is about to be completely disrupted. and we go deep into the technical architecture of his phone farms, his strategies for avoiding detection on social platforms, and how he's using what he calls attention intelligence to create content that gets better with every post. For those who don't know, this interview is brought to you by Superwall, the all-in-one platform for payw wall management and revenue analytics for your mobile apps. So it's like obviously like people have heard of viral content on Instagram and Tik Tok, but there's all this warm-up process and you are rate limited cuz they don't want you to spam. And it seems like kind of the only way around it is either you hire a bunch of people to just manually post on their phones, do some like VPNs and stuff, or you figure out how to do it with a virtual machines, but I'm sure it's it's kind of hard to fully automate. The traditional way is to hire a bunch of college age kids to make, you know, 30 videos in 30 days. That'll run you anywhere from like 500 bucks a month to $1,000 a month. And you don't even know if they're good. Usually, these people have no experience and you have to manage them all in some type of like Slack channel or like iMessage. And since you're college kids, sometimes they'll post, sometimes they won't. Sometimes they'll listen to your guidelines, sometimes they won't. And I know this because I used to be one of these creators. I started out being one of those creators. And I realized like, oh, if I don't post for a couple days, no one really cares. There's no accountability. I still get paid. And they care really about like, you know, one video doing well. Every week there's some type of like management call. There's like one person full-time managing all 25 of us. The ROI just isn't there. I've even tried running these campaigns like as an agency and also being part of them. And I just realized from a time perspective, from a money perspective, it's not worth it, especially if it's content that I can recreate with AI. So that's why when I started working for these brands more extensively, what I did was I used AI to run them. So I was working for 15 brands while in school, all using AI, but then the problem became how do I post this content? Because when you hire a bunch of kids, it's the kids, you know, posting on their devices. When you actually do the AI content yourself, there's no way to post. I think in 2023 I started using emulators to do this like an Android emulator on a computer. It would work on Windows computers. I would use Blue Stacks. However, that doesn't work today. Tik Tok has like device fingerprinting and they've, you know, any social media can can easily detect that now. So, the video that you're watching, all those phones are controlled by our software that's customuilt to swipe on Tik Tok, repost, comment, and everything to look like a natural human. >> That's crazy. So that's why I knew like the emulators don't work. I knew what they look for in terms of warming. I've been on the other side. Or if you only have the deployment figured out, then you need to figure out where to get the good creatives. We need to own the entire layer to actually be effective. We only do half the job, then we're worthless. We're just like everyone else. So that's why it's been like a pretty easy cell for us to just, you know, plug and play and make your accounts on our platform. You can schedule posts on our platform and you can create the post on our platform and you can hyper specify your post to like this account has a persona, this person is 24 years old, goes to USC, lives in Los Angeles, whatever. And this is actually like a genius idea for any restaurant. The reason being is because you get to control the reservations. So in a normal restaurant when you have like a 100 people getting seated, you take whatever reservations and you might only fill like 88 spots or you take a reservation for seven, you put it on a table for eight. What this allowed us to do was like, you know, take a reservation for eight and then adjust accordingly from like a seven-seater table and like add one more chair. I was like, "Okay, instead of just doing that, here's 100 bucks. Every time I I have a poster order, just make it for me and then like, you know, build my card afterwards." You'll have 20 pieces of content and each of them get zero or one click or two clicks which is kind of bad. It's not a good sample size but this is where the magic is. One of them will have like five or 10 clicks and then you're like asking wait was that a outlier? Was that random? Was it just chance but then you just continue the budget more and it either averages out and it was a fluke or you're on to something. So that's why I like this kind of like low sample size approach of finding very quickly across a lot of variety because whether it's in Facebook and Instagram, YouTube, Tik Tok, the creative makes the biggest difference. There's like targeting strategies. There's so many strategies to improve like the content or the ads. The creative is the biggest one that gives you like the 10x multipliers. the ones where the right creative will give you the 10 time difference as opposed to these small optimizations, which is after you have successful ads and a business model and customer journey, then you can like make these 10% improvements which help your bottom line and you kind of know your numbers better. That makes sense where like each month you make the improvement. But when you're looking for the biggest levers, that's when it should be the 10x differences and that's the creative. And then when you just put a few dollars on each one, you're amplifying that difference between the average creatives versus the one that has the strongest hook. And it just might be that expression in the face whether someone is annoyed or excited, you know, kind of like catches that attention. ## [24/28] Optimize paywalls for your mobile apps using Superwall. #subscriptionmodel #appmarketing #indiedev
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZx8fAL8Nvw
Words: 209

hey everyone Jordan from Super wall and I'm here today with one quick tip specifically around placements and it's this don't create one catch all placement instead create one for each action that you want to pay wall or maybe later want to pay wall cuz you can remotely activate or deactivate these you can see in my soccer app I've got about five placements here and I'll show you why that's valuable if I were to use the app and I'm not on a paid subscription when I take this action here I get a placement that I've set up the five now the reason this is great is if I were to say restart the app run it again I have another placement that fires after onboarding here's why this is really great now I can go into my dashboard and specifically I can look at the recent matches and you'll see here all of those placements are listed now what I can do is I can make a correlation between actions people were taking and when they upgraded to either a trial or a paid subscription and you can use that for optimization thanks for watching and I hope to see you soon using super wall
