## [27/28] this ai study app makes $100k/mo. here's how (no-code)
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zdbimhZjm7k
Duration: 25:44
Words: 5,290

Today we're taking a look at how Julian Alvarez built Jungle, an AI study app doing 80K to 100K in MR, but his story is nothing like what you've heard before. His path to get to that spot will challenge almost everything you've heard about building consumer apps. For [music] the next two weeks, don't touch the product. Don't touch it at all. Just spend the next two weeks focusing purely on distribution. Because if you focus two complete weeks on distribution and nothing happens, [music] then no one probably cares about your product. You see, most founders obsess over whether to focus on product or distribution, but Julian's lived through both extremes. From mass DMing 200 people and getting his Twitter banned to running 40 UGC creators posting 400 videos per week to generating 150 million total views, he's done some crazy numbers. >> We went from 2K MR to like almost 15K MR within like a week or two. [music] And that video alone, I think we estimate made us like close to 20K or so. And when one video from a micro influencer made them $20,000, Julian thought he'd cracked the code. But when he tried to replicate it, something unexpected happened. The strategy that seemed like an infinite growth hack turns out to be far more complex than he thought. But that's what makes Julian's insights so valuable. He's super honest about what did and didn't work. So today, he's breaking down why their influencer strategy eventually failed, the saturation problem killing traditional UGC right now, and why consumers are starting to catch on to inauthentic content. This sort of traditional UGC strategy is a growth hack. [music] And hacks of any sort are temporary. Like they won't work forever. And that's because by nature, a growth hack exploits a gap in the market. And eventually those gaps end up getting filled. And we go deep on when short-term optimization makes sense versus long-term plays, why retention is 10 to 100 times harder to move than top of funnel, and his contrarian take on whether bootstrap founders can actually afford to focus on retention. But that's enough of me just telling you about it. Let's get into the meat. I'm your host, Joseph Choy, founder of Consumer Club. For those who don't know, this interview is brought to you by Superwall, the all-in-one platform for paywall management and revenue analytics for your mobile apps. Let's get into it. To start out, tell me about Jungle. >> Yeah, so Jungle is an AI learning platform for students. It's kind of like a Quizlet with AI where you can upload anything you want to learn like a PDF, your lecture slides, a YouTube video, anything like that. And then we'll use that to generate practice questions of different sorts. Multiple choice questions, flashcards, open-ended questions of different difficulties. And it's also gified like Dualingo as you can kind of see like from the vibe of it. The whole idea is like how do we make effective active learning for students really easy and also really fun because it turns out that one of the biggest problems for students isn't always like learning efficacy or how effective their studying is. It's more so their motivation to show up every day and be consistent. And one of the most beautiful things about what we're doing is not just making learning effective with AI and learning science, but also making it really fun so that people can fall in love with learning as school originally do, but doesn't do a great job at. >> That's really cool. How much money is Jungle making right now? >> We are making around like 80 to 100K a month. >> How did you initially get started getting your first downloads and revenue? My co-founder David and I, we've been like obsessed with learning education and we had been doing like a lot of pivots previously, but when AI came into the picture, we're like, "Wow, this is like a huge opportunity to reimagine what uh learning and education could look like." And we were looking for an idea because we had pivoted like four or five times. Nothing was working. We had like 3 months of runway and we needed something that would work right now basically. And we saw this tweet someone put out that went viral where they basically said, "My dream AI product would be to take anything I'm learning and to generate flashc cards with it using AI." That tweet blew up and I commented saying we were building like something similar, which we were building something tangentially similar, but not the exact same thing. But basically, I got like over 200 downloads, over 50, 200 DMs, and basically just like a lot of interest in this. and it felt like the perfect opportunity for us to take advantage of in a space that we really cared about. And we basically got our first 100 users by DMing everyone that engaged with that tweet. So much to the point that my Twitter account got banned, which was really sad. From there on, like we had content creators pick it up and start creating videos about it. And then we posted our thing on AI tool directories, kind of like future tools, for example. And then finally getting to 10,000 plus ended up coming from influencer marketing. And we did influencer marketing as kind of like our growth strategy for quite some time. >> Yeah. It seems like you've done every stage of growth from mass DMing things that don't scale to everyone who likes to tweet all the way to like mass scale UGC programs. AI tool directory. Do you feel like that's still a big thing today? >> Probably not. I think I would still try to post the tool there, but my guess would be that they're probably oversaturated by now. Actually, like the more important sort of advice that I got when I first launched, my co-founder, David and I were very product oriented. He's kind of more designer, product thinker. I'm more of a technical person. And so marketing and growth wasn't really like a natural thing for us. It wasn't the thing we gravitated towards. One of our mentors told us that when we first launched, he was like, "Okay, great. You launch." Now, for the next two weeks, don't touch the product. Just spend the next two weeks focusing purely on distribution and nothing happens, then no one probably cares about your product and you should probably pivot. And for us, it was like there's a truth to that, but there was also a mindset shift that came with it. as a product person or as a technical person, you're always kind of like trying to think of like, oh, but there's this bug, there's this like thing we could add, this feature that we think would make a meaningful difference. And it's easy to get into this sort of like rat race. I think early on, you got to figure out a way to consistently get at least 30 to 100 people in the door per week. Ideally, a lot more, but at a minimum, like that amount, so that whenever you do release things or try different experiments out, you're able to at least get some sort of meaningful number of users trying it out to see if it actually works. >> So, after you took that advice and hey, let's just focus 2 weeks laser in on distribution, do you remember what the first kind of breakthrough moment was where you actually started to see some traction? Well, it was interesting the DMing hundreds of people to try the product. That was not the most effective way to grow, but it was a really effective way to get feedback because you're already opening a one-on-one like channel of communication. So, it's basically a lot easier for someone to share feedback through that versus if someone found your thing through TikTok. Like, there's not a direct channel of communication open. That was a really great way to get a lot of feedback early on, that one-on-one sort of marketing tactic. and then posting on the AI tool directories and having it get picked up by some influencers. There were some videos that started to go a little bit viral and that got a lot of people into the door just kind of gave us more validation on what we were building early on. So, was that almost like an early signal like you randomly posted on these directories hoping to get some users but then by chance people just influencers started mentioning you. Those posts did really well and then is that when you kind of realize like oh actually these posts by these influencers are doing well. maybe we should do influencer marketing. >> I think that was the natural sequence of thoughts where it's like, well, these people are organically making videos about us, but obviously that's limited in its [music] power and the number of people that would do it, especially after the newness factor of your app sort of dies down. I think also, by the way, the reason like influencers organically made videos is because it was like a pretty novel concept and cool idea at the time, like AI generated flashcards. Now, it feels like something that's very generic or not that exciting. So yeah, there's like a newness factor that makes it pretty interesting and fun. >> So then how did you do influencer marketing? Can you just walk through that strategy? >> Yeah, I mean we didn't really know what we were doing at the beginning or how it worked, but I think it was just basically finding influencers that were in our niche like the study space, study talk, and trying to get them to post videos. I think the like more advanced strategy that we ended up getting to after a couple iterations is target micro to mid-tier influencers like in the 5k to 100k followers range because the ROI and the CPMs at that time I think are a lot better versus like if you get really big influencers they're a lot more expensive. You know they don't always work out well so you're kind of gambling. But with the micro influencers it was like better guarantee that you would get a better ROI. The downside is that it's a lot more effort cuz you're reaching out to a lot more people. There's a lot in the process around, hey, try to do like a three or a multi- video deal in order to get like lower cost per video. And on top of that, like how do we best equip content and a sort of like plan to an influencer that sort of educates them on the pain points on viral hooks that have gone well, but also give them the creative freedom to express themselves. I think there was a a lot that we experimented with and finding the ideal balance between guiding and giving the best material possible to the influencers while also creating enough space for them to be creative and create things in the content style that best fits their own page. >> It seems like when you're working with micro influencers and you there's this concept of the brief, like you can't just have them make whatever video they want. You're kind of looking at good formats that have gone viral already within the niche. How did you actually think about that balance? I'm curious like what that strategy was between giving the influencer complete creative freedom versus saying here's actually how to make a video that'll convert to actual users. Yeah, there's a delicate balance. I think we have more of a benefit in that many of these influencers tend to be students themselves. So like they get it, they get the pain points, but at the same time they may not because they may know them, but they may not be consciously aware of them or how to talk about them. So, you want to provide like examples of videos that have performed really well or examples of viral hooks that they could potentially use. And of course, like give them feedback wherever feedback is warranted in order to to make it good. But it is hard cuz you have to train your own content intuition to know what works well. And this is a skill that neither my co-founder and I had. So I think like we have to sort of make content ourselves and really study content in order to develop good enough intuitions that would allow us to basically better guide and better vet the quality of any influencers we worked with. >> Yeah, I feel like it's actually like people like to over complicate it, but it's like anyone can literally make a TikTok. It's just your phone. You just record your face, talk to the camera, or just find a video that's doing well and just try to replicate it. But I remember this whole strategy has stuck in my mind for the past few years of knowing you guys. This is one of the first times that my mind was completely blown of like you can do micro influencer marketing and hit some big numbers with consumer apps. Was this like the first breakout video, would you say? >> Yeah, this um influencer uh Agogo, she's amazing. She makes really good content. She's in medical school, which is like in her niche of like the biggest power user. [music] And the quality of content she makes is just incredible. She like perfectly touched on the pain points in these videos, like had really good storytelling narrative, showed the product in a really compelling way. And yeah, she had maybe like three videos that got over a million views, this being one of them. It was insane. The first time we ever went like 10x viral was from one of her videos. It was pretty nuts. I can't remember exactly, but we went from 2K MR to like almost 15K MR within like a week or two. And that video alone, I think we estimate made us like close to 20K or so. So, you know, we feel like we won the lottery. I'll never forget that first viral moment. It was pretty surreal. >> Now, you have the winning lottery numbers, right? Cuz you're the one who kind of like strategized to make this video. Well, you know, you outsource the creativity a little bit to the creator, but you now have the data of like this type of video just made us 20k in revenue. So, are you then able to put in those same lottery numbers over and over and just kind of repeat the strategy or is there some more nuance there? >> Well, that was the big question. Like, great, we hit a home run. Can we do it again? And can we create a repeatable strategy around this? That was the big question at the time. And we were able to get a couple other like viral videos specifically from this creator, Agogo. But after some time like we weren't able to replicate it and we weren't able to like get similar success with other creators. We tried very hard. Maybe we just didn't know what the we were doing or we took the wrong approach. After some time like we were burning more money than we were making on these influencer videos. You know, we have to switch our approach. Is there anything you would have done differently if you knew that repeating the same influencer strategy wouldn't work the way that you wanted it to? >> I think one thing we didn't try as much is like minimum view clauses, right? That would have mitigated the risk. And I think overall, I feel like we could have done a much better job of seeing what worked or analyzing what worked and replicating that in a more strategic way. I don't know if it would have come from like just better briefs or better guidance, but there's definitely a lot of things that we didn't try, but it it felt expensive to keep on trying influencer marketing. >> So, the influencers were making some money and some downloads, but just not enough to justify the cost. >> Yeah, it definitely seemed like we were spending significantly more money than we were getting back. >> So, this was like 15k MR at this point when you just initially started a few videos within like a week or two. Now you're at, you know, 80, 100K a month. How did you get from 20K to where you are now? >> It's like product, right? Building a really good product, trying to improve retention as much as we can, increasing sharability and unlocking viral growth loops within the app. I still think there's a lot to do there, but we've done some things there. Yeah, around like 30 to 40% of all new users come from word of mouth. That's really important in terms of just like the virality of the app. And also that adds a force multiplier on all our distribution efforts. So product cloud growth I think it's super duper important and I think we've emphasized a good amount and also the like fun gamified element of the app I think is pretty big as well like jungle the whole brand narrative the storytelling the emotion that you provoke I think all of those things make a big difference >> you said 30 40% of new users come from word of mouth what do you feel like is the biggest lever that really moves that metric >> like one what's your magic what's the aha moment and then two what's your time to magic basically how long does does it take for a first-time user to experience the magic? And we've iterated and run hundreds of experiments on our landing page that you're showing here. And one of the most successful ones is basically being able to upload a document or a URL directly from the landing page. And you'll see here that this directly goes through the whole funnel of like generating questions. And our product experience for firsttime users is substantially different than it is for like second, third time users or basically anyone after that. We try to minimize and make it as simple as possible. Like we don't show you all these options of like what range of minutes or pages you want and rate for, what type of questions do you want, how many questions you want. These are all things you don't see in the first product experience because we want to keep it as simple as possible. We even have like a mini review here of like, hey, answer your first like seven questions. Like we make it really really like bite-sized so you can get through it, experience the core value and then we introduce the whole set of features after you complete like this first initial mini review. I think like just making sure you have really good magic and reducing the time to magic is one core thing and how good the app is. And then other than that, it's literally trying to make sharing as prominent as possible throughout the app. Oh, also the gamified element. You see this tree that's growing here as you're answering questions. One, that tree increase engagement by 70%. Basically, like the core engagement metric of answering a lot of questions, but it's also a really good growth hack. If you're in a library and you're studying on your computer and someone walks by you and sees this like tree growing, they're like, "Yo, what is that tree?" And it's sort of interesting growth loop in itself just through like the visual component. And this also speaks to one of the core benefits of targeting students, which is that students are in very close clusters with each other. Like they're at a university campus or high school campus or whatever it is. So they're likely to overlap and look at each other's screens. And so the visual component I think makes a big difference in word of mouth as well. That's underrated. How does it visually look on the screen? Not just to the user, but when people look at a screen, they're in the physical world and there might be other people looking at it. Another thing I'm noticing about this onboarding is you get the user to the the magic moment right away. It's like landing page to input your slides and then it immediately generates questions and you have an interactive demo. You can see the tree growing. You get the the answers wrong and it explains to you why you got it wrong. I hit the payw wall and then I said maybe later instead of signing off immediately. And then you go to when is the exam? So I'm like okay it's in 2 weeks. It's almost like the payw wall continues now. So like can you walk me through like how you thought about this part? >> Let's say that 50% of people complete like upload something and get to the checkpoint. All right. Well, if you show a payw wall, that means that 50% of people that complete the mini review or do this first experience will see the payw wall. Versus if you only show the payw wall after the first time you generate and only like 25% of people get there, then you're basically missing out on a 25% chunk that never even saw the payw wall. So this is true for almost anything right like and that's why some people have very long onboarding. So one thing we also strategically do is like we split our onboarding into three main phases. So one is just like signing up at the beginning which is after you generated questions then we ask you to sign up. Here's like the second part which is choose what exam this is for if you said you're a student or turn on notification reminders. If you're on mobile which we have a mobile app then it'd be turn on push notifications there. And then if you were to go back to the home screen after like doing this review, then you will get your like final sort of onboarding. Here's an upsell as well if you want more questions. Here's also part of the onboarding which is like to select your little character. This is pretty cute. This is like a little jungle river and as you gain XP you move through the river and if you get to the end you level up and as you level up you unlock new trees and other rewards. At the end here you see like the key topics that were a part of this review and like how you performed on them. You can like keep studying, retry the ones you missed. And then this is like the third onboarding step basically. So how did you hear about us? This is how we know that like 30 to 40% of people come from friends. What's your weekly goal? you see that we've kind of like split on boarding to be at these different sort of steps to not overwhelm the user especially like if they haven't really meaningfully tried the whole thing yet. >> Going back to that question, you tried some product things, you tried some growth things. Do you have any hot takes or any I guess just nuance takes cuz I feel like you see it all the time on people on Twitter, people fighting about distribution is more important than products or products more important than distribution. Do you have any takes on that? >> I have a lot and I'm still conflicted. So firstly, almost everyone knows this thing like first time founders focus on product, second time founders focus on distribution as if you're like stupid for focusing on product. My take is third- time founders realize that both are important, right? It's not one or the other. It's like both matter. But obviously when you're very early on, like focus is your most important thing. But I do think you get to a certain point in the company like where we're at, you have to do both to an extent. But you can say like, "Oh, I'm going to focus 80% of my efforts on distribution and 20% on product or vice versa." But I think you got to do both eventually. >> One thing you said that really stuck out to me was when you have retention, you have more chances at monetization. I feel like for some people it's kind of a foreign concept because it's just the hard payw wall meta where it's like you acquire the user, you hard payw wall. If they don't pay then it's just it's over. You acquire a new user. In your guys' case, you acquire the user, you have a premium experience. You still show the payw wall pretty early in the onboarding, but you still allow the user to use the product for free and continue to add value with retention and eventually you convert those users later. Like you said, it requires a little bit more patience, a little bit more capital maybe to design the product in that way. Uh, do you feel like venture-backed companies are the only ones that are able to do this style of product where it's like premium or do you think that bootstrap founders are still able to really focus on retention and not hard payw walling? I think bootstrap founders can 100% focus on like the retentive product approach, but it's harder to like emphasize that if you are not cash flow positive. Like if you feel like you're in survival mode or you don't have that much money, then you're gonna like feel the need to be like, "Hey, how do we make the most amount of money like right now?" And usually that's going to lead you to distribution. The way to make the most money right now or to grow the most right now is not retention. Retention is a long-term play. And not only because you don't really see the benefits of good retention until like a little further down the line, but also because it's literally the hardest metric to move. Let's go to UGC. So, where we left off is you started doing influencer marketing. You maybe got lucky, maybe didn't, but it went very well, but it didn't quite scale. And now you're at 2, three, four times the revenue that you were at. Yeah. Break down your UGC strategy. Essentially, the core idea behind UGC is you get creators. These are usually people without as much experience. You can get very experienced one as well. just depends on your strategy whether you want to go for very high quality creators or kind of like people that are newer to it. They create their own separate accounts and we basically have them post like 10 to 12 videos a week. Very high content throughput at like 30 creators. That means we're getting like close to 400 videos per week. So very high content throughput. And the whole idea is that these people pose as students that like discovered this amazing tool jungle and are kind of like wanting to share the alpha in an organic way. The whole idea is that you feel like you're discovering this tool from this person that's being very generous about sharing about it or talking about it. There's a lot that we do internally to train the creators, get them to do well, give them feedback on videos, and so yeah, that's been something we've been developing a lot. But that's the core of the idea. And it works well for the most part. Like we're able to get basically like around $2 CPMs or so. That varies a little bit up and down, but it's pretty good and way better than influencer marketing. It's hard to know for sure, but it does feel like profitable overall. But there is a dilemma here that I think is very interesting, and that is that this sort of traditional UGC strategy is a growth [music] hack. And hacks of any sort are temporary. like they won't work forever and that's because by nature a growth hack exploits a gap in the market and eventually those gaps end up getting filled but yeah I think like this UGC strategy is short-lived because the more it works the more people that do it and honestly right now like almost every brand is doing UGC this sort of UGC strategy so like the amount of content that's coming out is completely saturating the market I feel like or at least it's starting to just think about it if you're a consumer and you like going on Tik Tok to watch like study videos like study talk and now like every third or fifth video is like this thing that seems organic but is actually someone just trying to push a product you're like I don't know this doesn't feel authentic I don't think these people are actually promoting product and then if you actually go to one of their profiles you realize that all their videos are mentioning this same tool it's a very inauthentic thing in a way >> another thing I like to ask people is if you're just starting out or you have a product that's maybe around 10k MR and you're trying to scale, you know, you have some profitability, what's kind of like the first lever or the first thing that you should be really prioritizing? >> The race to the top is very nonlinear. It can take a while. It's very hard and many of our growth moments have come like almost unexpectedly after trying a lot of things and and getting there. So that's why I think experimentation is so important. I think your biggest skill set to build as a founder is the ability to figure anything out. Like we didn't really know growth and growth intimidated us, but we didn't give a we just strapped in and got our hands dirty and tinkered with different strategies until we found something that worked and then it stopped working and then we tried new things and now it works and now it's like not working as well and now we're going to try new things and it's an endless cycle. It's very hard but that's also what makes it really fun is the challenge behind it. >> Great advice. This is a great pod. >> Absolutely. Thank you for having me. It was fun to riff and see what the hell comes out of my mouth. >> That's awesome. All right, that was a good one. By the way, I'm the host, Joseph Choy, founder of Consumer Club, which is a private group for ad founders to talk to each other about the latest tactics. Median revenue of member is about a million ARR. Check it out. Check out Superwall, too. They're the best. And check out the other interviews on the Super Wall channel. See you in the next one.

## [28/28] This 23 Yr Old Genius Makes $1M/Year with No-Code Apps. Here's How
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zpTXi8WxeM0
Duration: 48:07
Words: 10,456

Think about the classic trap that most app founders are stuck in. Build an app, ship it, and then hope people will download it. But Connor, the guy I talked to today, is doing something completely different. He's 23 years old. He's making over a million a year. And he's done it by completely flipping how app developers think about distribution. His main app payout is pulling in $45,000 a month. And almost all of that is coming from one place, influencers. But here's the thing, he [music] actually doesn't pay the influencers to make posts. Instead, he gives them equity and then builds the app specifically for their audience. >> You know, I built this app specifically around his audience. Like before we had an idea of what we're going to build, like I was like, okay, this is, you know, what his audience does like is looking for. I actually went through a list of like maybe five ideas of different apps and I made some like Figma mockups for them. I was like, which one of these do you think like resonates the most with your with your audience because I think these all have potential to convert off of it. >> Of course, this is the complete opposite of how most people approach influencer partnerships. You build the app first, then try to convince an influencer to promote it. Connor asks the influencer what their audience wants and then builds it. And because the influencer now has equity in the app, they actually care about making it succeed. And so the videos they make are getting high views and convert well. >> You're going to actually find that these influencers you're working with are very entrepreneurial, like they can be gritty and get stuff done. >> But here's the problem. How do you even reach these influencers in the first place? Most founders make the same mistake. They slide into DMs and it doesn't work. But Connor figured out something way better. >> There's absolutely no reason to to try to DM these larger creators. Like it was funny. I emailed them in maybe April. And just like a week ago, one of these influencers responded like, "Hey, like you know, just remembered about this email. Hopped on a call with them. Like I explained to them like, oh, this is, you know, this is your account. This isn't [music] what I think we could build." And they seemed super interested in it. So now like that's moving forward. So I would say email is much better. So now he's got the influencer, he's got the audience, he's got the equity deal, but how does he know which app idea will actually work? It seemed almost too good to be true how every launch seems to go so well. The members in the Consumer Club Discord, and the founders I interview on the pod build apps at a median of about a million dollars ARR. But one thing you might not know is Superwwell has a lot of data on the thousands of apps that use their payw walls. You can use it for free at paywallexperiments.com. All right, let's get into the pod. Yeah, I I think you're one of the first people I've talked to that cross post to Facebook video. I mean, a lot of people talk about Instagram reels, Tik Tok, YouTube Shores. Those are like the big three, but then of course there's still Facebook video. And if you for some reason have the Facebook app still installed on your phone, if you go onto the video tab, there's a lot of views on those videos actually. But I've noticed that theme as well, like a lot of influencers are pretty unmon like undermonetized um or they're making like decent money, but it feels like a hamster wheel because it's not stable. And a lot of people, I think in the dev world, don't quite understand that psychology because as a dev, you're usually like working at a company and you have a stable income and you actually want the opposite. You want the freedom. But on the other side, as a creator, you have the freedom, but you also have to like eat what you kill. You can't you don't just get money for doing your work. Like you have to chase after these brand deals, negotiate all the time, and it's not consistent. One thing that yeah, like the business savvy thing is I also feel like that's a relatively new concept in the like creator influencer world because originally when Instagram came out and there were influencers, most people thought of influencers as people that do like basically beauty products and get ready with me and like dancing videos. And yeah, those people are not they're not the the type of people that are like grinding to like build a business. They're they're kind of just like sharing their lifestyle and making some money from it from brand deals here and there. Versus this type of creator, this guy, you know, he has 100k followers, but the followers are very niche. They're about, you know, about mountain biking, which is like and he's providing like expert almost like expertise content or like expert content within this niche. So, are there niches, like obviously this is a very good niche, are there niches that you gravitate towards or niches that you avoid when you're thinking about partnering with um like expert creators like this? >> Yeah, that's a good question. And I'd say like even when I'm building apps myself right now, like it's kind of an optimization problem where the larger app you build, there's going to be larger competitors is one thing. And there's going to be more people bidding for those eyeballs. Like if you were trying to compete with, you know, in a beauty fashion, there's a lot more people. So that's like the balancing factor. It's like a lot more people, but you're also competing with Kim Kardashian and all sorts of people that are, you know, have these massive followings and lots of money to spend on their uh user acquisition. So, I found like there's a good and if you go too deep uh and you pick something that's like, you know, an app that teaches dogs how to do handstands or something like you're never going to find anyone that's going to pay for your app. But there is a good middle ground. And I tend to think of it like, okay, you got super broad, super niche. I go like right in the middle and then I go like slightly more niche. And that's where I where I kind of try to build apps right now. Especially because my goal is to make apps that are somewhere between, you know, 30 to maybe a couple hundred,000 of revenue a month. That's like kind of my goal for the apps I'm building right now. Um, I'm not trying to build something that's going to make $10 million a month right now because I want to kind of train my skills a little bit more, learn more about the industry. While I do think like, you know, maybe it's possible I could do it, it's just uh it'd be nice to have like the capital and like the confidence to to build that. And also like as I've built more apps that are like kind of slowly scaling up, like I've met more people, I'm like, "Wow, this would be someone I would like absolutely love to partner with on like a larger project." And then I build like a slightly larger project. And in the process, I meet someone else. I'm like, "Wow, this person would be super cool to build a project with, too." and then next thing you know like I'm operating with like all these people who are like you know in the top 1% of their field and it's like I would love to work with any of these people on any of these projects. Um which I think is super cool. Yeah, I'd say like especially for people who are trying to start out trying to build an app. If you're trying to look for an influencer, like find something that's kind of niche, like uh you know, like this uh guy Justin has a hundred followers on 100 thousand followers on Instagram. Like as far as the creator scale goes, like he's still a small creator. Like he's there's creators out there with, you know, probably 100 million followers on Instagram. But you can see like he's still able to drive tens of thousands of downloads. Like that's going to be more than enough users for most people to be able to have an app that they consider successful in their eyes. Um, you know, maybe like Disney is not going to reach out to this guy instead of building an app because like they're building massive things. But yeah, >> that's a good like entrepreneurship framework in general, too, because I I feel like a lot of people start out with, okay, what do people want? Like build something that people want and but that's just too broad of a of a question. It's like you need to figure out, okay, what do people want that also has the level of execution risk that matches with my experience? So, if you've never built a $30,000 a month business before, then why are you trying to build a $500,000 a month business that has like a ton of competition from all these like big players that have a lot of leverage already? >> Yeah, that's definitely something that I like see a lot of um like being in San Francisco, like there's so many people that are trying to build these massive companies. They go through Y Combinator and they're raising all this money and we're going to build a10 billion dollar unicorn. And I think it's kind of funny because these people are like maybe they dropped out of college, maybe they're like just finished high school. Like they have not done they have no reason to believe they should do this besides confidence. And like that can get you really far. Um but I think like they would be so much more successful if they started off bootstrapping. Um or maybe even just raising a small amount and building something that's like decent. You know, it's like you don't have to go straight from like zero experience to building like the next sales force. Like you might as well start off, spend like a year or two, build something that makes enough money that look, I never have to pay for food or rent or anything like that ever again. I learned all this about negotiating, about optimizing these funnels. Um, and then you can go and like build whatever you want because you have these connections. You have a lot of understanding. >> That sounds like a a great setup to me. like you you make some money. You never have to pay rent. You learned a bunch of stuff. Learned how to build funnels. You built connections with people that you respect. Who cares if you didn't build a billion [laughter] dollar company. Like maybe you can do it now. Like now that you've built this like really great business, that's cool. Like what what in your journey led you to that conclusion where you decided like, hey, I actually want to build a business that is around this ambition level. Like what's your like motivation? One thing that like is super uh I think I guess can like I consider unique about the way that I operate is like I think I operate like very much like I don't really plan things honestly like um I pretty much never use a calendar for anything ever. I don't have like deadlines that I set for myself. Um I basically wake up in the morning I'm like I'm just going to do what I think is the highest leverage thing. And there's a degree of like foresight like I'm not just like a lizard that can only think 30 minutes in the future. But um it's definitely a lot of like I'm going to figure out what the highest leverage thing is in this like shorter time window. Like if you ask me what I'm doing 2 weeks from now or where I'll be in two weeks from now, I have no clue. No idea. Like that's not I don't think that far ahead. Um so I'd say like I just see that that as the highest leverage thing. I wouldn't say like I planned out like okay I'm going to slowly upgrade my uh ambition levels for these companies. And I think it kind of just ended up that way based off of me deciding that was the highest leverage thing to do. Like when I first started building apps, it was purely out of just like I had an app idea for like some social event app that would um you know you could post a pin on the map and anyone could see that pin and like you know if you wanted to have a pickup basketball game you put it on the map and like anyone nearby could come join you for that pickup basketball game. And I built that app and then that, you know, I got to a point where I was like, "All right, I like this app, but I'm ready to start something new." And that first app got to maybe like a couple thousand a month. And then I built a second app and that got to like, you know, a couple 10 20,000 a month. And then, you know, slowly kind of just ended up that way rather than uh really planning it out. >> That's interesting. Like the um like the IRL map, like hang out with friends app. I feel like that's generally the first type of app that most entrepreneurs think of. It's like what do I like to do? I like to hang out with friends. Okay, >> what's a software that I can use to uh make that easier? Okay, I'll make an IRL like friend hangout app. But you actually make money with the classic one >> which is a little bit more. I feel like a lot of people those apps and then nobody downloads it. >> No, that one never made money. Uh that one's you know that that was my first app that was um much more of a learning project. >> Yeah. >> Uh but it gave me the confidence to build than my next app that was able to make money. >> Is that how you're thinking about this one too? I I was looking at your um app store profile and you you're this is the posture um yeah >> calisthenics app you're talking about. >> Oh no, this is a different one. Uh this is just a posture app. Um >> yeah, >> like targeted exclusively to posture. Uh, this app I honestly kind of built. Uh, but I immediately had another idea that I wanted to build right after and I didn't spend the time distributing this. It's done maybe somewhere around $45,000 in in revenue over the past couple months. So, it's not like completely dead. Um, but it is not as monetized as I think it should be. And I actually am talking with some influencers about like potentially making this app like curated for them. um like you know there's like these little guys in the pictures and whatnot. I was like, "You know what? Like, what if I find one of these influencers who has a couple million followers and I just say like, "Hey, I'm gonna replace every single one of these guys with a picture of you doing the exercise and we're going to make this like your app and you're going to drive your couple million eyeballs to this and like you'll get an app pretty much that's finished and I don't have to think about distribution for this cuz I don't really want to because I've, you know, this like I was saying with my like I was kind of leveling up like, oh, I did this app and then this app was bigger and this app was bigger." This one kind of just got caught in the middle of like an app that was bigger than this one right after and it's like well all right like I guess I'm just gonna like it's like maybe not as high leverage. But uh I really like this app. I think >> it's one of my favorite apps that I've built honestly. Uh I put a lot of time into like making his little random like >> quality features that like didn't really weren't super valuable but I it was fun to build. >> Yeah. Yeah. That's a that's another like good application of the framework that we already talked about which is like think about what is the highest leverage thing I can do right now and for this app like the highest leverage thing you could do if you had nothing else to do would be to reach out to tons of influencers find people who do posture videos find people who do fitness videos maybe partner with as an equity partnership with one of them and then pay the rest um and then evolve the app But because you don't want to do that and you have other ideas, like you don't want to just let it die. So, what's the highest leverage thing for this specifically is to just like give a bunch of equity to like one influencer and like let them handle everything and then you basically have to do nothing. Um >> Oh, yeah. >> Like let them promote. Yeah. And you're not going to get much revenue out of it as you could, but you're not just like, you know, letting it die. >> Yeah. Like I have two options here. here. It's like I let this sit here and make, you know, some revenue or like if I gave away I would be willing to give away like who knows like 60 70% of this app cuz I'm not going to do anything with it. And like maybe they're able to bring in $10,000 of revenue a month and it's like all right that's better than doing nothing with it. And it's like there's always a lot of these I think this is one thing that's like sunken cost where it's like people like oh but I built this app like I'm not going to sell it like I'll do something with it later. It's like no you're not you're not going to do something with it later. Maybe you are but probably not. So, just figure out something to do with it that's high leverage, move on to the next thing. Yeah. Like there's been people that I've reached out to and I see an app that I like on the app store cuz honestly the same way like people will scroll on Tik Tok, Instagram, like I try not to do that. Um the highest leverage they could do for this app that's been they haven't updated it in two years. They're not it's not making any money. It's like you should just sell it to me but they're not going to. Um because they have some sort of sunken cost like oh I spent a couple months building it. >> Yeah. Yeah. >> Or maybe it's like an art piece to them. In that case totally justified. They like the app because they made it and they like how it looks. But um a lot of the times I think the best opportunity for those people should be like just figure out what the highest leverage thing to do is assuming you're going to go do something else. >> Yeah. Yeah, >> that's really good advice. Yeah. I feel like a lot of people have a almost like a hoarders mentality. I I get stuck in this myself. like people offer to buy this or that or like partner and I'm like and then you like the temptation is to maximize every single opportunity and then you negotiate too hard and then and then it just doesn't go through and then later you're like oh actually it probably would have been better to have a win instead of like zero like a small win is better than zero like sure you can try to optimize for the big win but you know if the opportunity isn't right in front of you like kind of just it's these these small wins can compound. Yeah, exactly. That's the that's the thing. It's like, okay, maybe for this app here, like if somebody offered me a couple thousand dollars for it, like I'd have to really think, okay, like a couple months, maybe I would make that. But if they offered me like, you know, $10,000 for this app, I would be like, you know what? Like, why not? I'll sell that. It would give me some more capital to spend on influencers for future projects. You know, maybe I get like a Twitter post that goes viral that's like, I just sold this app. You know, a lot of people maybe that turns into like me being able to connect with somebody that is, you know, someone I've been wanting to connect with. Who knows? And the alternative is like I just like you know potentially make that money over the next year. It's like who knows see if I can turn this into something that is worthwhile. So >> yeah I guess to to close out one thing you said is you scroll the app store to get inspiration. Are there any other habits or mindsets that you have dayto-day that you feel like give you good inspiration for ideas? One thing like like I was kind of mentioning before is like I like try to be as present as possible in any given moment and it's become a habit at this point. I don't have to like act and be like oh like I need to you know whatever. It's like I'm not meditating constantly. But I think that allows me to I'm like constantly thinking about the things I'm doing. Like I'm not thinking about things I need to do. I'm not thinking about things I did in the past. Like I'm just kind of like analyzing things and then when new problems come up I think I'm very aware of like this being a problem and then deciding like is this something that I think I am interested in solving. I guess one way to describe it is like keeping like your horizon that you're looking at like kind of vague and like hazy in the sense that like don't have your mind entirely set on what you're trying to do and like don't just like march forward blindly, but instead like if you can kind of pay more attention to what you're actually like doing in your like more local environment, then it has a lot of benefits that a lot of people don't think about. They're way too focused on what's what next year's goal is. Like think about like today's goal. Yeah. >> Thanks so much, Connor. This is a great This is a great talk.
